titleStmt.title: The historie of Troylus and Cresseida As it was acted by the Kings Maiesties seruants at the Globe. Written by William Shakespeare.
Troilus and Cressida
titleStmt.author: Shakespeare, William, 1564-1616.

publicationStmt.publisher: Imprinted by G. Eld for R. Bonian and H. Walley, and are to be sold at the spred Eagle in Paules Church-yeard, ouer against the great north doore,

div.p: THE Historie of Troylus and Cresseida. As it was acted by the Kings Maiesties seruants at the Globe.
LONDON Imprinted by G. Eld for R. Bonian and H. Waller, and are to be sold at the spred Eagle in Paules Church-yeard, ouer against the great North doore. 1609.

div.head: The history of Troylus and Cresseida.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: CAll heere my varlet, Ile vnarme againe,
Why should I warre without the walls of Troy:
That finde such cruell battell here within,
Each Troyan that is maister of his heart,
Let him to field Troylus alas hath none.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Will this geere nere be mended?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: The Greeks are strong and skilfull to their strength
Fierce to their skill, and to their fiercenesse valiant,
But I am weaker then a womans teare;
Tamer then sleepe; fonder then ignorance,
Lesse valiant then the Virgin in the night,
And skillesse as vnpractiz'd infancy:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Well, I haue told you enough of this; for my part ile not meddle nor make no farther; hee that will haue a cake out of the wheate must tarry the grynding.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Haue I not tarried?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I the grindin●; but you must tarry the boulting.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Haue I not tarried?

sp.speaker: Pa●de.
sp.p: I the boulting; but you must tarry the leauening.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Still haue I tarried.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I, to the leauening, but heares yet in the word hereafter, the kneading, the making of the cake, the heating the ouen, and the baking, nay you must stay the cooling too, or yea may chance burne your lippes.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Pacience her selfe, what Godesse ere she be,
Doth lesser blench at suffrance then I do:
At Priams royall table do I sit
And when faire Cressid comes into my thoughts,
So traitor then she comes when she is thence.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Well shee lookt yesternight fairer then euer I saw her looke, or any woman els.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I was about to tell thee when my heart,
As ●edged with a sigh would riue in twaine,
Least Hector or my father should perceiue mee:
I haue (as when the Sunne doth light a scorne)
Buried this sigh in wrincle of a smyle,
But sorrow that is coucht in seeming gladnesse,
Is like that mirth fate turnes to suddaine sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: And her haire were not some-what darke● then Hellens, well go to, there were no more comparison betweene the women ● but for my part she is my kinswoman, I would not as they tearme it praise her, but I would som-body had heard her talke yester-day as I did, I will not disprai●e your sister Cassandras wit, but—

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Oh Pandarus I tell thee Pandarus,
When I do tell thee there may hopes lie drown'd
Reply not in how many sadomes deepe,
They lie indrench'd● I tell thee I am madde:
In Cressids loue? thou answe●st she is faire,
Powrest in the open vlcer of my heart:
Her eyes, her haire her cheeke, her gate, her voice,
Handlest in thy discourse: O that her hand
In whose comparison all whites are ynke
Writing their owne reproch; to whose soft seisure,
The cignets downe is harsh, and spirit of sence:
Hard as the palme of plow-man; this thou telst me,
As true thou telst me, when I say I loue her,
But saying thus in steed of oyle and balme,
Thou layst in euery gash that loue hath giuen mee
The knife that made it.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.l: I speake no morethen truth.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Thou dost not speake so much.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Faith Ile not meddle in it, let her bee as shee is, if she bee fai●e tis the better for her, and shee bee not, she has the me●ds in her owne hands.

sp.speaker: Tro●.
sp.p: Good Pandarus. how now Pandarus

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: I haue had my labour for my trauell, ill thought on of her, and ill thought of you, go● betweene and betweene, but small thanks for my labour.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: What are thou angry Pandarus? what with me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Because sh●e's kin to me therefore shee's not so faire as Hellen, and she were kin to me, she would be as faire a Friday as Hellen, is on Sunday, but what I? I care not and shee were a black eamore, tis all one to mee.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Say I she is not faire?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do not care whether you do or no, she's a foole to stay behinde her father let her to the Greekes, and so Ile tell her the next time I see her for my part Ile meddle nor make no more ith'matter.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Sweete Pandraus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray you speake no more to mee I will leaue all as I found it and there an end.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Peace you vn●racious clamors, peace rude sounds,
Fooles on both sides, Hellen must needes be faire,
When with your bloud you daylie paint her thus,
I cannot fight vpon this argument:
It is too staru'd a subiect for my sword,
But Pandarus: O gods▪ how do you plague me
I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar,
And he's as teachy to be wood to woe,
As she is stubborne, chast, against all suite.
Tell me Apollo for thy Daphnes loue
What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we:
Her bed is India there she lies, a pearle,
Betweene our Ilium, and where shee reides
Let it be cald the wild and wandring stood:
Our ●el●e the Marchant, and this sayling Pandar,
Our doubtfull hope, our conuoy and our barke.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: How now prince Troylus, wherefore not a field,

sp.speaker: Tro●.
sp.l: Because not there; this womans answer sorts,
For woman 〈◊〉 it is to be from thence.
What newes Aeneas from the field to day?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: That Paris● returned home and hurt.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: By whom Aeneas?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Troylus by Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Let Paris bleed tis but a scar to scorne,
Paris gor'd with Menelaus horne.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Harke what good sport is out of towne to day.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Better at home, if would I might were may:
But to the sport abrode are you bound thither?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: In all swift hast.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come goe wee then togither.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Who were those went by?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Queene Hecuba, and Hellen.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: And whether goe they?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Vp to the Easterne tower,
Whose hight commands as subiect all the vaile,
To see the battell: Hector whose pacience,
Is as a vertue fixt, to day was mou'd:
Hee chid Andromache and strooke his armo●er,
And like as there were husbandry in warre
Before the Sunne rose, hee was harnest lyte,
And to the field goes he; where euery flower
Did as a Prophet weepe what it foresawe,
In Hectors wrath.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What was his cause of anger.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: The noise goes this, there is amonge the Greekes,
A Lord of Troian bloud, Nephew to Hector.
They call him. Aiax.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Good; and what of him,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They say hee is a very man perse and stands alone.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So do all men vnlesse the are dronke, sicke, or haue no legges.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: This man Lady, hath rob'd many beasts of their particular additions, hee is as valiant as the Lyon, churlish as the Beare, slowe as the Elephant: a man into whome nature hath so crowded humors, that his valour is crusht into folly, his folly sauced with discretion: there is no man hath a vertue, that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint, but he carries some staine of it. Hee is melancholy without cause and merry against the haire, hee hath the ioynts of euery thing, but euery thing so out of ioynt, that hee is a gowtie Briareus, many hands, & no vse: or purblinde Argus, al eyes, and no sight.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: But how should this man that makes me smile, make Hector angry.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They say hee yesterday cop't Hector in the battell and stroke him downe, the disdaine and shame whereof hath euer since kept Hector fasting and waking.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Who comes here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Maddam your vncle Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Hector a gallant man.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: As may be in the world Lady.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Whats that? whats that?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Good morrow vncle Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Good morrow cozen Cressid: what doe you talke of? good morrow Alexander: how doe you cozen● when were you at Illum?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: This morning vncle.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What were you talking of when I came? was Hector arm'd and gon ere yea came to Illium, Hellen was not vp was she?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Hector was gone but Hellen was not vp?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: E'ene so, Hector was stirring early.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: That were wee talking of, and of his anger.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Was he angry?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So he saies here.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: True hee was so; I know the cause to, heele lay about him to day I can tel them that, & ther's Troylus wil not come farre behind him, let them take he●de of Troylus; I can tell them that too.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: What is he angry too?

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Who Troylus? Troylus is the better man of the two:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: Oh Iupiter ther's no comparison.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: What not betweene Troylus and Hector? do you know a man if you see him?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: I, if I euer saw him before and knew him:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Well I say Troylus is Troylus:

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Then you say as I say, for I am sure hee is not Hector,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No not Hector is not Troylus in some degrees.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Tis iust, to each of them he is himselfe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Himselfe, alas poore Troylus I would he were.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So he is.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Condition I had gone bare-foot to India.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: He is not Hector.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Himselfe? no? hee's not himselfe, would a were himselfe,
well the Gods are aboue, time must friend or endwell Troylus well, I would my heart were in her body; no, Hector is not a better man then Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Excuse me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: He is elder.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Pardon me, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Th'others not come too't, you shall tell me another tale when th'other's come too't, Hector shall not haue his will this yeare.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: He shall not neede it if he haue his owne.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Not his qualities.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: No matter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nor his beautie.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Twould not become him, his own's better.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: You haue no iudgement neece; Hellen her selfe swore th'other day that Troylus for a b●owne fauour (for so tis I must confesse) not browne neither.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: No, but browne.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Faith to say truth, browne and not browne.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: To say the truth, true and not true.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: She praisd his complexion aboue Paris.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Why Paris hath colour inough.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: So he has.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Then Troylus should haue too much, if shee praizd him aboue, his complexion is higher then his, hee hauing colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion, I had as lieue Helens golden tongue had commended Troylus for a copper nose.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I sweare to you I thinke Helen loues him better then Paris.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Then shees a merry greeke indeed.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Nay I am sure she dooes, she came to him th'other day into the compast window, and you know hee has not past three or foure haires on his chinne.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Indeed a Tapsters Arith●●etique may soone bring his particulars therein to a totall.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Why he is very yong, and yet will he within three pound liste as much as his brothers Hector.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Is he so yong a man, and so old a lifter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: But to prooue to you that Hellen loues him, shee came and puts mee her white hand to his clouen chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 haue mercy, how came it clouen?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why, you know tis dimpled, I thinke his smyling becomes him better then any man in all Ph●igia.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Oh he smiles valianty.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Dooes hee not?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Oh yes, and twere a clowd in Autumne.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Why go to then, but to proue to you that Hellen loues Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Troylus wil stand to thee proofe if youle prooue it so.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Troylus, why hee esteemes her no more then I esteeme and addle egge:

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: If you loue and addle egge as well as you loue and idle head you would eate chickens ith shell.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I cannot chuse but laugh to thinke how she ticled his chin, indeed shee has a mar●el's white hand I must needs confesse.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Without the rack.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And shee takes vpon her to spie a white heare on his chinne.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Alas poore chin many a wart is ritcher.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But there was such laughing, Queene Hecuba laught that her eyes ran ore.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: With milstones.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And Cassandra laught.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: But there was a more temperate fire vnder the por of her eyes: did her eyes run ore to?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And Hector laught.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: At what was all this laughing.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Marry at the white heare that Hellen spied on Troylus chin.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: And t'had beene a greene heare I should haue laught too.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: They laught not so much at the heare as at his pretty answere.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: What was his answere?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Quoth shee heere's but two and fifty heires on your chinne; and one of them is white.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: This is her question.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Thats true, make no question of that, two and fiftie
heires quoth hee, and one white, that white heire is my father, and all the rest are his sonnes. Iupiter quoth shee, which of these heires is Paris my husband? the ●orked one quoth he, pluckt out and gaue it him: but there was such laughing, and Hellen so blusht, and Paris so chaft, and all the rest so laught that it past.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So let it now for it has beene a great while going by.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Wel cozen I ●ould you a thing yesterday, think on't.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: So I doe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Ile be sworne tis true, he will weepe you an'twere a man borne in Aprill

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: And Ile spring vp in his teares an'twere a nettle against May.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Harke they are comming from the field, shall we stand vp here and see them as they passe toward Ilion, good Neece do, sweete Neece Cresseida.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Heere, here, here's an excellent place, here wee may see most brauely, iletell you them all by their names, as they posse by, but marke Troylus aboue the rest.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Speake not so lowde.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Thats Aeneas, is not that a braue man, hees one of the flowers of Troy I can tell you, but marke Troylus, you shal see anon.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That's Antenor, he has a shrow'd wit I can tell you, and hee's man good enough, hees one o'th soundest iudgements in Troy whosoeuer, and a proper man of person, when comes Troylus, ile shew you Troylus anon, if hee see me, you shall see him nod at mee.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will he giue you the nod:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You shall see:

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: If he do the ritch shall haue more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That's Hector, that, that, looke you ●hat, thers a fellow! goe thy way Hector, ther's a braue man Neece, O braue Hector, looke how hee lookes, theres a countenance, ist not a braue man?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: O a braue man.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Is a not? it dooes a man heart good, looke you what hacks are on his helmet, looke you yonder, do you see, looke you there, thers no iesting, thers laying on, takt off, who will as they say, there be hacks.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Be those with swords.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Swords, anything he cares not, and the diuell come to him, its all one, by Gods lid it dooes ones heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris, looke yee yonder Neece, ist not a gallant man to, ist not, why this is braue now, who said he came hurt home to day. Hee's not hurt, why this will do Hellens heart good now ha? would I could see Troylus now, you shall see Troylus anon.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Whos's that?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That's Helenus, I maruell where Troylus is, thats Helenus, I thinke he went not forth to day, thats Helenus.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: Can Helenus. fight vncle?

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Helenus no: yes heele fight indifferent, well, I maruell where Troylus is; harke doe you not here the people crie Troylus? Helenus is a priest;

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Panda:
sp.p: Where? yonder? that's Deiphobus. Tis Troylus! theres a man Neece▪ hem? braue Troylus the Prince of chiualrie.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Peace for shame peace.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Marke him, note him: O braue Troylus, looke well vpon him Neece, looke you how his sword is bloudied, and his helme more hackt then Hectors, and how hee lookes, and how hee goes? O admirable youth, hee neuer saw three and twenty, go thy way Troylus, go thy way, had I a sister were a grace, or a daughter a Goddesse, hee should take his choice, O admirable man! Paris? Paris is durt to him, and I warrant Hellen to change would giue an eye to boote.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Here comes more.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p:
Asses, fooles, doults, chaff & bran, chaff & bran, porredge after meate, I could liue and die in the eyes of Troylus, nere
looke, nere looke, the Eagles are gonne, crowes and dawes, crowes and dawes, I had rather bee such a man as Troylus, then Agamemnon and all Greece.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: There is amongst the Greekes Achilles a better man then Troylus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Achilles, a dray-man, a porter, a very Cammell.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Well well:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Well, well, why haue you any discretion, haue you any eyes, doe you know what a man is? is not birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, man-hood, learning, gentlenesse, vertue youth, liberallity and such like, the spice & salt that season a man.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: I a minst man, and then to bee bak't with no date in the pie, for then the mans date is out:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You are such a woman a man knowes not at what ward you lie:

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Vpon my backe to defend my bellie, vpon my wit to defend my wiles, vpon my secrecy to defend mine ●onesty, my maske to defend my beauty, and you to defend all these: and at al these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Say one of your watches.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Nay Ile watch you for that; and thats one of the chiefest of them two: If I cannot ward what I would not haue hit: I can watch you for te●ling how I tooke the blowe vnlesse it swell past hiding and then its past watching:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: You are such another:

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: Sir my Lord would instantlie speake with you.

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: At your owne house there he vnarmes him:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Good boy tell him I come, I doubt he be hurt, fare ye well good Neice:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: Adiew vncle:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: I wil be with you Neice by and by:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: To bring vncle:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: I a token from Troylus:

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: By the same token you are a Bawde,
Words, vowes, guifts, teares and loues full sacrifize:
He offers in anothers enterprize,
But more in Troylus thousand fould I see,
Then in the glasse of Pandars praise may bee:
Yet hold I off: women are angels woing,
" Things woone are done, ioyes foule lies in the dooing.
That shee belou'd, knows naught that knows not this,
" Men price the thing vngaind more then it is,
That she was neuer yet that euer knew
Loue got so sweet, as when desire did sue,
Therefore this maxim out of loue I teach,
" Atchiuement is command; vngaind beseech,
Then though my hearts content firme loue doth beare,
Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appeare.

div.stage: Enter Agamemnon▪ Nestor, Vlisses, Diomedes, Menelaus with others.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Princes: what griefe hath set these Iaundies ore your cheekes?
The ample proposition that hope makes,
In all designes begun on earth below,
Failes in the promist largenesse, checks and disasters,
Grow in the vaines of actions highest reard.
As kno●● by the con●lux of meeting sap,
Infects the sound Pine, and diuerts his graine,
Tortiue and errant from his course of growth.
Nor Princes is it matter new to vs,
That we come short of our suppose so farre,
That after seauen yeares siege, yet Troy walls stand,
Sith euer action that hath gone before,
Whereof we haue record, triall did draw,
Bias and thwart: not answering the ayme,
And that vnbodied figure of the thought,
That gau't surmised shape: why then you Princes,
Do you with cheekes abasht behold our workes,
And call them shames which are indeed naught else,
But the protractiue tryals of great loue,
To finde persistiue constancie in men.
The f●nenesse of which mettall is not found,
In fortunes loue: for then the bould and coward,
The wise and foole, the Artist and vnread,
The hard and soft se●m ●●ll aff●n'd and ●in,
But in the winde and tempest of her frowne,
Distinction with a broad and powerfull fan,
Puffing at all, winnowss the light away,
And what hath masse or matter by it selfe,
Lyes rich in vertue and vnmingled.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: With due obseruance of the godlike seate,
Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply
Thy latest words. In the reproofe of chance,
Lies the true proofe of men: the sea being smooth,
How many shallow bauble boate, dare ●aile,
Vpon her ancient brest, making their way
With those of nobler bulke?
But let the ●uffian Boreas once enrage
The gentle Th●t is, and anon, behold
The strong ribbd barke through liquid mountaines cut,
Bounding betweene the two moyst elements,
Like Perseus horse. Where's then the sawcie boate,
Whose weake vntymberd sides but euen now
Corriuald greatnesse? either to harbot fled,
Or made a toste for Neptune: euen so
Doth valours shew, and valours worth deuide
In stormes of fortune; for in her ray and brightnesse
The heard hath more annoyance by the Bryze
Then by the Tyger, but when the splitting winde,
Makes flexible the knees of knotted Okes,
And Flies fled vnder shade, why then the thing of courage,
As rouzd with rage, with rage doth simpathize,
And with an accent tun'd in selfe same key,
Retires to chiding fortune.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Agamemnon,
Thou great Commander, nerues and bone of Greece,
Hea●t of our numbers, soule and onely spright,
In whom the tempers and the minds of all
Should be shut vp: heere what Vlisses speakes,
Besides th'applause and approbation,
The which most mighty (for thy place and sway
And thou most reuerend) for the stretcht out life,
I giue to both your speeches; which were such
As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece,
Should hold vp high in brasse, and such againe
As venerable Nestor (hatcht in siluer)
Should with a bond of ayre strong as the Axel-tree,
(On which heauen rides) knit all the Greekish cares
To his experienc't tongue, yet let it please both
Thou great and wise, to heare Vlisses speake.
Troy yet vpon his bases had beene downe,
And the great Hectors sword had lackt a master
But for these instances.
The specialtie of rule hath beene neglected,
And looke how many Grecian tents do stand,
Hollow vpon this plaine, so many hollow factions,
When that the generall is not like the hiue,
To whom the forragers shall all repaire,
What honey is expected? Degree being visarded
Th'vnworthiest shewes as fairly in the maske.
The heauens them-selues, the plannets and this center
Obserue degree, prioritie and place,
In sisture, course, proportion, season forme,
Office and custome, in all line of order.
And therefore is the glorious planet Sol,
In noble eminence enthron'd and spherd,
Amidst the other; whose medcinable eye,
Corrects the influence of euill Planets,
And posts like the Commandment of a King,
Sans check to good and bad. But when the Planets,
In euill mixture to disorder wander,
What plagues, and what portents, what mutinie?
What raging of the sea, shaking of earth?
Commotion in the winds, frights, changes, horrors
Diu●rt and crack, rend and deracinate,
The vnitie and married clame of states
Quite from their fixure: O when degree is shakt,
Which is the ladder of all high designes,
The enterprise is sick. How could communities;
Degrees in schooles, and brother-hoods in Citties,
Peacefull commerce from deuidable shores,
The primogenitie and due of birth,
Prerogatiue of age, crownes, scepters, lawrels,
But by degree stand in authentique place:
Take but degree away, vntune that string,
And harke what discord followes, each thing melts
In meere oppugnancie: the bounded waters
Should lift their bosomes higher then the shores,
And make a sop of all this solid globe:
Strength should be Lord of imbecilitie,
And the rude sonne should strike his father dead.
Force should be right or rather right and wrong,
(Betweene whose endlesse iarre Iustice recides)
Should loose their names, and so should lustice to?
Then euery thing include it selfe in power,
Power into will will into appetite,
And appetite an vniuersall Woolfe,
(So doubly seconded with will and power)
Must make perforce an vniuersall prey,
And last eate vp himselfe.
Great Agamemnon,
This chaos when degree is suffocate,
Followes the choaking.
And this neglection of degree it is,
That by a pace goes backward with a purpose
It hath to clime. The generalls disdaind,
By him one step below, he by the next,
That next by him beneath, so euery step,
Exampl'd by the first pace that is sick
Of his superior, growes to an enuious feauer
Of pale and bloudlesse emulation,
And 'tis this feauer that keepes Troy on foote,
Not her owne sinnews. To end a tale of length,
Troy in our weaknesse stands not in her strength.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: Most wisely hath Vlisses here discouerd,
The feuer whereof all our power is sick.

sp.speaker: Agamem.
sp.l: The nature of the sicknesse found Vlisses
What is the remedie?

sp.speaker: Vlisses.
sp.l: The great Achilles whom opinion crownes,
The sinnow and the fore-hand of our hoste,
Hauing his care full of his ay●ie same,
Growes dainty of his worth, and in his Tent
Lies mocking our designes: with him Patroclus
Vpon a lazie bed the liue-long day,
Breakes scurrell iests,
And with ridiculous and sillie action,
Which (slanderer) he Imitation calls,
He pageants vs. Some-time great Agamemnon,
Thy toples●e deputation he puts on,
And like a strutting Player, whose conceit
Lyes in his ham-st●ing, and doth thinke it rich
To heere the woodden dialogue and sound,
Twixt his stretcht footing and the scoaffollage,
Such to be pitied and ore-rested seeming,
He act● thy greatnesse in▪ And when he speakes,
Tis like a chime a mending, with termes vnsqua●e,
Which from the tongue of roaring Tiphon dropt,
Would seeme hiperboles, at this fustie stuffe,
The large Achilles on his prest bed lolling,
From his deepe chest laughes out alowd applause,
Cries excellent; 'tis Agamemnon right,
Now play me Nest●r, hem and stroake thy beard,
As he being drest to some Oration,
That's done, as neere ●s the extremest ends
Of paralells as like as Vnlcan and his wife:
Yet god Achilles still cries excellent,
Tis Nestor right: now play him me Patroclus,
Arming to answer in a night alarme,
And then forsooth the faint defects of age,
Must be the scaene of myrth, to coffe and spit,
And with a palsie fumbling on his gorget,
Shake in and out the riuet, and at this sport
Sir valour dyes, cryes O enough Patroclus,
Or giue me ribbs of steele, I shall split all
In pleasure of my spleene, and in this fashion,
All our abilities guifts, natures shapes,
Seueralls and generalls of grace exact,
Atchiuements, plots, orders, preuentions,
Excitements to the field, or speech for truce,
Successe or losse, what is, or is not, 〈◊〉
As stuffe for these two▪ to make paradoxes.

sp.speaker: Nestor.
sp.l: And in the imitation of these twaine,
Who as Vlisses sayes opinion crownes,
With an imperiall voyce: many aro infect,
Aiax is growne selfe-wild, and beares his head
In such a reyne, in full as proud a place
As broad Achilles: keepes his Tent like him,
Makes factious f●asts, railes on our state of warre,
Bould as an Oracle, and sets Thersites
A slaue, whose gall coynes standers like a mint,
To match v●in comparisons with durt,
To weaken our discredit, our exposure
How ranke so euer rounded in with danger,

sp.speaker: Vlisses.
sp.l: They taxe our-pollicie; and call it cowardice;
Count wisdome as no member of the warre,
Forstall prescience, and esteeme no act
But that of hand, the still and mentall parts,
That do contri●e how many hands shall strike,
When fitnesse calls them on, and know by measure
Of their obser●ant royle the enemies waight,
Why this hath not a fingers dignitie,
They call this bed-worke, mappry, Closet warre,
So that the Ram that batters downe the wall,
For the great swinge and rudenesse of his poise,
They place before his hand that made the engine,
Or those that with the 〈◊〉 of their soules,
By reason guide his execution.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Let this be granted, and Achilles horse
Makes many 〈◊〉 sonnes,

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What trompet? looke Menelaus▪

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: From Troy.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: What would you fore our tent

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Is this great Agamemnons tent I pray you?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Euen this.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: May one that is a Herr'ald and a Prince,
Do a faire message to his Kingly eyes?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: With surrty strong erth on Achilles 〈◊〉
Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voice,
Call Agamemnon head and generall.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Faire leaue and large security, how may
A stranger to those most imperiall lookes,
Know them from eyes of other mortals?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: I, I aske that I might waken reuerence,
And bid the cheeke be ready with a blush,
Modest as morning, when shee coldly eyes the youthfull Phoebus,
Which is that god, in Office guiding men,
Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: This Troyan scornes vs, or the men of Troy,
Are c●remonious Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Aene,
sp.l: Courtiers as free as debonaire, vnarm'd
As bending Angels, thats their same in peace:
But when they would seeme soldiers, they haue galls,
Good armes, strong ioints, true sword, & great loues accord
Nothing so full of heart: but peace Aeneas,
Peace Troyan, lay thy finger on thy lips,
The worthinesse of praise distaines his worth,
If that the praisd him-selfe bring the praise forth.
But what the repining enemy commends,
That breath fame blowes, that praise sole pure transcends.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Sir you of Troy, call you your selfe Aeneas?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: I Greeke, that is my name.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Whats your affaires I pray you?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Sir pardon, 'tis for Agamemnons cares.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: He heeres ●●ught priuately that comes from Troy.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper with him,
I bring a trumpet to awake his ●are,
To set his seat on that attentiue bent,
And then to speake.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Speake frankly as the winde,
It is not Agamemnons sleeping houre;
That thou shalt know Troyan he is awake,
Hee tels thee so himselfe.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Trumpet blowe alowd,
Send thy brasse voyce through all these lazie tents,
And euery Greeke of m●trell let him a now,
What Troy meanes fairely, shall be spoke alowd,
We haue great 〈◊〉 herre in Troy,
A Prince calld Hector, 〈◊〉 is his father,
Who in his dull and long continued truce,
Is restie growne: H● bad me take a Trumpet,
And to this 〈◊〉 speake, Kings, Princes, Lords,
If ●here be one among the fair'st of Greece,
That holds his honour higher then his case,
And feeds his praise, more then he feares his perilt,
That knowes his 〈…〉 ● knowes not his feare,
That loues his 〈◊〉 more then in confession,
(With truant vowes to her owne lips he loues)
And dare avowe her beautie, and her worth,
In other armes then hers: to him this challenge;
Hector in view of Troyans and of Greekes,
Shall make it good or do his best to do it:
He hath a Lady, wiser, fairer, truer,
Then euer Greeke did couple in his armes,
And will to morrow with his Trumpet call;
Mid-way betweene your tents and walls of Troy,
To rouze a Grecian that is true in l●●e;
If only come; Hector shall honor him▪
If none, hee le say in Troy wheir he 〈◊〉,
The Grecian dames are sun-burnt, and not worth
The splinter of a Launce. Euen so much▪

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: This shall be told our louers Lord Aeneas,
If none of them haue soule in such a 〈◊〉.
We 〈◊〉 them all at 〈◊〉, we are souldiers,
And may that souldier a 〈◊〉 recreant prooue,
That meanes not, hath 〈◊〉, or is not in loue:
If then one is, or hath a meanes to be,
That one meetes Hector: if none else I am 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Tell him of Nestor, 〈◊〉 was a man
When Hectors 〈…〉 ● He is old now,
But if there be not in our Grecian hoste,
A noble man that hath no sparke of fire
To answer 〈…〉 ●
Ile hide my siluer ●eard in a gould beauer,
And in my vambrace put, my 〈◊〉 braunes
And meeting him tell him that my Lady,
Was fairer then his grandam, and as chast,
As may bee in the world (his youth in flood)
Ile proue this troth with my three drops of bloud,

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Now heauens for-send such 〈◊〉 of men▪

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Amen▪ faire Lord Aeneas let me touch your hand,
To our pauilion shall I leade you 〈◊〉;
Achilles shall haue word of this intent,
So shall each Lord of Greece from tent to tent,
Your selfe shall feast with vs before you goe,
And finde the welcome of a noble soe.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Nestor.

sp.speaker: Nest:
sp.l: What saies Vlisses?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: I haue a yong conception in my braine,
Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What ist?

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: Blunt wodges true hard knots, the seeded pride,
That▪ hath to this mat●rity blowne vp
In ranke Achilles, must or now be cropt,
Or shedding breede a noursery of like euill,
To ouer-bulk vs all.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Well and how?

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: This challeng that the gallant Hector sends,
How euer it is spread in generall name
Relates in purpose onely to Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: True the purpose is perspicuous as substance,
Whose grofensse little characters sum vp▪
And in the publication make no straine,
But that Achilles weare his braine, as barren,
As banks of libi● (though Apollo knowes
Tis dry enough) will with great speed of iudgement,
I with celerity finde Hectors purpose, pointing on him.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: And wake him to the answere thinke you?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Why tis most meete; who may you else oppose▪
That can from Hector bring those honours off,
If not Achilles: though't be a sportfull combat.
Yet in the triall much opinion dwells:
For here the Troyans tast our de●rst repute,
With their fin'st pallat, and tru●● to me Vlissis
Our imputation shalbe odly poizde
In this vilde action, for the successe,
Although perticuler shall giue a scantling
Of good or bad vnto the generall,
And in such indexes (although small pricks
To their subsequent volumes) there is seene,
The baby figure of the gyant masse,
Of things to come at large: It is suppos'd
He that meetes Hector, yssues from our choice,
And choice (being mutuall act of all our soules)
Makes merit her election, and doth boyle,
(As twere from forth vs all) a man distill'd
Out of our vertues, who miscarrying,
What heart receiues from hence a conquering part,
To steele a strong opinion to them selues.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Giue pardon to my speech? therefore tis meete,
Achilles meete not Hector, let vs like Marchants
First shew foule wares, and thinke perchance theile sell;
If not; the luster of the better shall exceed,
By shewing the worst first: do not consent,
That euer Hector and Achilles meet,
sp.p: For both our honour and our shame in this, are dog'd with two strange followers.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I see them not with my old eyes what are they?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector
Were he not proud, we all should share with him:
But he already is too insolent.
And it were better par●ch in Afrique Sunne,
Then in the pride and sault scorne of his eyes
Should he scape Hector faire. If he were foild,
Why then we do our maine opinion c●ush
In taint of our best man. No, make a lottry
And by deuise let blockish Aiax draw
The sort to fight with Hector, among our selues,
Giue him allowance for the better man,
For that will phisick the great Myrmidon,
Who broyles in loud applause, and make him fall,
His crest that prouder then blew Iris be●ds,
If the dull brainlesse Aiax come safe off
Weele dresse him vp in voices, if he faile
Yet go we vnder our opinion still,
That we haue better men, but hit or misse,
Our proiects life this shape of sence assumes
Aiax imploy'd plucks downe Achilles plumes.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now Vlisses I begin to relish thy aduise,
And I will giue a taste thereof forthwith,
To Agamemnon, go we to him straight
Two curres shall came each other, pride alone
Must arte the mastiffs on, as twere a hone.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Agamemnon, how if he had bites, full, all ouer, generally.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: And those byles did run (say so), did not the generall run then, were not that a botchy coro.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Dogge.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Then would come some matter from him, I see none now.

sp.speaker: Aia:
sp.p: Thou bitchwolfs son canst thou not heare, feele then.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: The plague of Greece vpon thee thou mongrell beefe witted Lord.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Speake then thou vnsalted leauen, speake, I will beate thee into hansomnesse.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I shall sooner raile thee into wit and holinesse, but I thinke thy horse will sooner cunne an oration without booke, then thou learne praier without booke, thou canst strike canst thou? a red murrion ath thy Iades trickes.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: T●de-stoole? learne me the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Doost thou thinke I haue no sence thou strikest mee thus?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: The proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Thou art proclaim'd foole I thinke.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Do not Porpentin, do not, my fingers itch:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I would thou didst itch from head to foote, and I had the scratching of the, I would make thee the lothsomest scab in Greece, when thou art forth in the incursions thou strikest as glow as another.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I say the proclamation.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thou gromblest and raylest euery houre on Achilles, and thou art as full of enuy at his greatnesse, as C●rb●rus is at Proser●inas beauty, I that thou barkst at him.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Mistres Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thou shouldst strike him. Aiax Coblofe, Hee would punne thee into shiuers with his fist, as a sayler breakes a bisket, you horson curre. Do? do?

sp.speaker: Aiax:
sp.p: Thou stoole for a witch:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I, Do? do? thou sodden witted Lord, thou hast no more braine then I haue in mine elbowes, an Asinico may cutor thee, you scuruy valiant asse, thou art heere but to thrash Troyans, and thou art bought and sould among those of any wit, like a Barbarian slaue. If thou vse to beate mee I will beginne at thy heele, and tell what thou art by ynches, thou thing of no bowells thou.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: You dog:

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: You scun●y Lord.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: You curre.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Mars his Idiot, do rudenesse, do Camel, do, do.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Why how now Aiax wherefore do yee thus,
How now Thersites whats the matter man.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: You see him there? do you?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: I whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Nay looke vpon him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: So I do, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Nay but regard him well.

sp.speaker: Achil:
sp.p: Well, why so I do.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: But yet you looke o● well vpon him, for who some euer you take him to be he is Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: I know that foole.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I but that foole knowes not himselfe.

sp.speaker: Aiax:
sp.p: Therefore I be ate thee.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he vtters, his euasions haue eares thus long, I haue bobd his braine more then he has beate my bones. It will buy nine sparrowes for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the ninth part of a sparrow: this Lord (Achilles) Aiax, who weares his wit in his belly, and his guts in his head, I tell you what I say of him.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I say this Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Nay good Aiax.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Has not so much wit.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Nay I must hold you.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: As will stop the eye of Hellens needle, for whom he comes to fight.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Peace foole?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I would haue peace and quiet●esse, but the foole will not, he there, that he: looke you there?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Oh thou damned cur●e I shall—

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Will you set your wit to a fooles.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: No I warrant you, the fooles will shame it.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Good words Thesites.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Whats the quarrell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I bad the vile oule goe learne mee the ●enor of the proclamation, and he railes vpon me.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I serue thee not?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Well, go to, go to.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I serue here voluntary.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Your last seruice was suffrance: twas not voluntary, no man is beaten voluntary, Aiax was here the voluntary, and you as vnder an Impresse.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: E'ene so, a great deale of your witte to, lies in your sinnewes, or els there bee hers, Hector shall haue a great catch and knocke at either of your beains, a were as good crack a sust● nut with no kernell.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: What with me to Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: The●s Vlisses and old Nestor, whose wit was mou●dy ere their grandsiets had nailes, yoke you like draught oxen, and make you plough vp the wars.

sp.speaker: Achil
sp.p: What? what?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Yes good sooth to Achill●, to Aiax, to—

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I shall ●ut out your to ●●ue.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Tis no matter, I shall speake as much as thou afterwards.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: No more words Thersites peace.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I will hold my peace when Achilles brooch bids me, shall I?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: There's for you Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: I will see you hang'd like Clatpoles, ere I come any more to your tents, I will keepe where there is wit stirring, and leaue the faction of fooles.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: A good riddance.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Marry this sir is proclaim'd through all our hosle,
That Hector by the first houre of the Sunne.
Will with a trumpet twixt our Tents and Troy,
To morrow morning call some Knight to armes,
That hath a stomack, and such a one that dare,
Maintaine I know not what, (tis rash) farewell—

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Farewell, who shall answer him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I know not, ●is put to lottry, otherwise,
He knew his man.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: O meaning you? I will go learne more of it.

div.stage: Enter Prian, Hector, Troylus, Paris and Helenus.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: After so many houres, liues, speeches spent,
Thus once againe saies Nestor from the Greekes:
Deliuer Hellen, (and all domage els,
As honour, losse o● time, trauell, expence,
Wounds, friends and what els deere that is con●i●m'd
In hot digestion of this cormoraut warre)
Shalbe stroke off, Hector what say you to't?

sp.speaker: Hect:
sp.l: Though no man lesser seares the Greekes then I
As sarre as toucheth my particular yet dread Priam
There is no Lady of more softer bowells,
More spungy to suck in the sence of feare:
More ready to cry out, who knowes what followes
Then Hector is: the ●ound of peace is surely
Surely secure, but modest doubt is calld,
The be●●on of the wise, the tent that serches,
Too'th bottome of the worst let Hellen go,
Since the first sword was drawne about this question
Euery tith soule 'mongst many thousand dismes,
Hath beene as deere as Hellen. I meane of o●●s,
If we haue loste so many ●enthes of ours,
To guard a thing not ours, not worth to vs,
(Had it our name) the valew of one ten,
What merits in that reason which denies,
The yeelding, of her vp?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Fie, fie, my brother,
Way you the worth and honour of a King:
So great as our dread fathers in a scale
Of common ounces? will you with Com●ters summe,
The past proportion of his infinite
And buckle in, a waste most ●atho●les,
With spanes and inches so dymi●u●●e▪
As feares and reasons: Fie for Godly shame?

sp.speaker: Hele.
sp.l: No maruell though you bite so sharpe of reasons,
You are so empty of them should not our father;
Beare the great sway of his affaires with reason,
Because your speech hath none that tell him so?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: You are for dreames and slumbers brother Priest,
You furre your gloues with reason, here are your reasons
You know an enemy intends you harme:
You know a sword imployde is perilous
And reason flies the obiect of all harme.
Who maruells then when Helenus beholds,
A Gretian and his sword, if he do set
The very wings of reason to his heeles,
And 〈◊〉 like chidden Mere●ry from Io●e
Or like a starre disorbd? nay if we talke of reason,
Sets shut our gates and sleepe: man-hood and honour,
Should haue hare hearts, would they but fat their thoughts
With this cram'd reason, reason and respect,
Make lyuers pale, and lush hood deiect.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.p: Brother, shee is not worth, what shee doth 〈◊〉 the keeping.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Whats aught but as tis valued.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: But valew dwells not in perticuler will,
It holds his estimate and dignity,
As well wherein tis precious of it selfe
As in the prizer, tis madde Idolatry
To make the seruice greater than the God,
And the will dotes that is attributiue;
To what ' infectiously it selfe affects,
Without some image of th'affected merit,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I take to day a wise, and my election▪
Is led on in the conduct of my will,
My will en●indled by mine eyes and eares,
Two traded pilots twixt the dangerous shore,
Of will and Iudgement: how may I auoyde?
(Although my will distast what it elected)
The wife I choose, there can be no euasion,
To blench from this and to stand firme by honor,
We turne not backe the silkes vpon the marchant
When we haue soild them, nor the remainder viands,
We do not throw in vn●espectue siue,
Because we now are full, it was thought meete
Paris should do some vengeance on the Greekes.
Your breth with full consent bellied his ●ailes,
The seas and winds (old wranglers) tooke a ●tuce:
And did him seruice, hee toucht the ports desir'd▪
And for an old aunt whom the Greekes held Captiue,
He brought a Grecian Queene, whose youth and freshnesse,
Wrincle, Apolloes, and makes pale the morning.
Why keepe we her? the Grecians keepe our Aunt,
Is she worth keeping? why shee is a pearle
Whose price hath lansh'● aboue a thousand ships:
And turn'd 〈◊〉 Kings to Marchants,
If youle 〈◊〉 twas wisdome Paris went,
As you mast needs, for you all cri'd go, go,
If youle confesse be brought home worthy prize:
As you must needs, for you all, clapt your hands,
〈…〉 ● why do you now
The yss●e of your proper wisdomes rate,
And do a deed that neuer fortune did,
Begger the estimation, which you 〈◊〉
Ritcher then sea and land? O thest most base,
That wee haue stolne, what we do feare to keepe,
But theeues vnworthy of 〈◊〉 so stolne:
That in their country did them that disgrace,
We feare to warrant i● our natiue place.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Cry Troyans cry:

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: What noise? what shrik is this?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Tis our madde 〈◊〉 I do know h●● voice.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Cry Troy●●s.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: It is Cassandra!

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Cry Troyans cry, 〈◊〉 thousand eyes,
And I will fill them with prophetick teares.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Peace sister peace▪

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Virgins and boyes, mid-age, and wrinckled elders,
Soft in●ancie, that nothing canst but cire,
Adde to my clamours: et vs pay be-times
A moytie of that masse of mone to come:
Crie Troyans crye, practise your eyes with teares,
Troy must not bee, nor goodly I lion stand.
Our fire-brand brother Paris burnes vs all,
Crie Tro●aus crie, a Holen and a woe.
Crie, crie, Troy burnes, or else let Hellen goe.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Now youthfull Troylus, do not these high straines
Of diuination in our S●ster, worke
Some touches of remorse? or is your bloud
So madly hott, that no discourse of reason,
Nor feare of bad successe in a bad cause,
Can qualifie the same?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Why brother Hector,
We may not thinke the iustnesse of each act
Such, and no other then euent doth forme it,
Nor once deiect the courage of our mindes,
Because Cassandra's madde, her brain-sick raptures
Cannot distast the goodnesse of a quarrell,
Which hath our seuerall honors all engag'd,
To make it gratious. For my priuate part,
I am no more toucht then all Priams sonnes:
And Ioue forbid there should be done amongst vs,
Such things as might offend the weakest spleene,
To fight for and maintaine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Else might the world conuince of leuitie,
As well my vnder-takings as your counsells,
But I attest the gods, your full consent,
Gaue wings to my propension, and cut off
All ●eares attending on so dire a protect,
For what (alas) can these my single armes?
What propugnation is in one mans valour
To stand the push and enmitie of those
This quarrell would exc●te? Yet I protest
Were I alone to passe the difficulties,
And had as ample power, as I haue will,
Paris should nere ●etract, what he hath done,
Nor faint in the pursuite,

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Paris you speake
Like one be-sotted on your sweet delights,
You haue the hony still, but these the gall,
So to be valiant, is no praise at all.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Sir, I propose not meerly to my selfe,
The pl●asures such a beautie brings with it,
But I would haue the soile of her faite rape,
Wip't of in honorable keeping her,
What ●reason were it to the ●ansackt queene,
Disgrace to your great worths, and shame to me▪
Now to deliuer her possession vp
On tearmes of base compulsion? can it be,
That so degenerate a straine as this,
Should once set footing in your generous bosomes?
There's not the meanest spirit on our party,
Without a heart to dare, or sword to drawe,
When Helen is defended: nor none so noble,
Whose life were ill bestowd, or death vnfam'd,
Where Helen is the subiect. Then I say,
Well may we fight for her, whom we know well,
The worlds large spaces cannot paralell.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Paris and Troylus, you haue both said well,
And on the cause and question now in hand,
Haue glo●d, but superficially, not much
Vnlike young men, whom Aristotle thought
Vnfit to heere M●rrall Philosophie;
The reasons you alleadge, do more conduce
To the hot passion of distempred blood,
Then to make vp a free dete●mination
Twixt right and wrong: for pleasure and reuenge,
Haue eares more deafe then Adders to the voyce
Of any true decision, Nature craues
All dues be rendered to their owners, Now
What neerer debt in all humanitie,
Then wife is to the husband▪ if this lawe
Of nature be corrupted through affection
And that great mindes of partiall indulgence,
To their benummed wills resist the same,
There is a lawe in each well-orderd nation,
To curbe those raging appetites that are
Most disobedient and refracturio;
If Helen then be wife to Sparta's King,
As it is knowne she is, these morrall lawes
Of nature and of nations, speake alowd
To haue her back returnd: thus to persist
In doing wrong, extenuates not wrong,
But makes it much more heauie. Hectors opinion
Is this in way of truth: yet nere the lesse,
My spritely brethren▪ I propend to you
In resolution to keepe Helen still,
For 'tis a cause that hath no meane dependance,
Vpon our ioynt and seuerall dignities.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Why there you toucht the life of our designer
Were it not glory that we more affected,
Then the performance of our heauing spleenes,
I would not wish a drop of Troy an bloud,
Spent more in her defence. But worthy Hector,
She is a theame of honour and renowne,
A spurre to valiant and magnanimous deeds,
Whose present courage may be ate downe our foes,
And fame in time to come canonize vs,
For I presume braue Hector would not loose
So rich aduantage of a promisd glory,
As smiles vpon the fore-head of this action,
For the wide worlds reuenew.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I am yours,
You valiant offspring of great Priamus,
I haue a roisting challenge sent amongst
The dull and factious nobles of the Greekes,
Will shrike amazement to their drowsie spirits,
I was aduertizd, their great generall slept,
Whilst emulation in the armie crept:
This I presume will wake him.
sp.p: How now Thersites? what lost in the Labyrinth of thy furie? shall the Elephant Aiax carry it thus? he beates me, and I raile at him: O worthy satisfaction, would it were otherwise: that I could beate him, whilst hee raild at mee: Sfoote, ●Ile learne to coniure and raise Diuels, but Ile see some issue of my spitefull execrations. Then ther's Achilles, a rare inginer. If Troy bee not taken till these two vndermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of them-selues, O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Io●e the king of gods: and Mercury, loose all the Serpentine craft of thy Caduceus, if yee take not that little little lesse then little witte from the● that they haue: which short-armd Ignorance it selfe knowes is so aboundant scarce, it will not in circumuention delurer a flie from a spider, without drawing their massie Irons▪ and cutting the web. After this the vengeance on the whole ca●●pe, or rather the Neopolitan bone-ache: for that me thinkes is the curse depending on those that warre for a p●acket. I haue said my prayers, and diuell Enuie say Amen. What ho my Lord Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patrocl.
sp.p: Whose there? Thersites? good Thersites come in and raile.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: If I could a remembred a guilt counterfeit, thou couldst not haue slipt out of my contemplation: but it is no matter, thy selfe vpon thy selfe. The common curse of mankinde, Folly and Ignorance, be thine in great reuenew: Heauen blesse thee from a tutor, and discipline come not neere thee. Let thy bloud be thy direction till thy death: then if she that layes thee out sayes thou art not a faire course, Ile be sworne and sworne vpon't, shee neuer shrowded any but lazars. Amen. Where's Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: What art thou deuout? wast thou in prayer?

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: I the heauens heare me.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Thersites my Lord.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p:
Where? where? O where? art thou come why my
cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not serued thy selfe into my table, so many meales, come what's Agamemnon?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thy commander Achilles, then tell me Patroclus, whats Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Thy Lord Thersites. Then tell mee I pray thee, what's Thersites?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Thy knower, Patroclus: then tell me Patroclus, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Thou must tell that knowest.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: O tell, tell.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Ile decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles, Achilles is my Lord, I am Patroclus knower, and Patroclus is a foole.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Deriue this? come?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Agamemnon is a foole to offer to command Achilles, Achilles is a foole to be commanded. Thersites is a foole to serue such a foole, and this Patroclus is a foole positiue.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Why am I a foole?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Make that demand of the Prouer, it suffices mee thou art: looke you, who comes heere?

div.stage: Enter Agam: Vliss: Nestor, Diomed, Aiax & Calcas.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Come Patroclus, Ile speake with no body: come in with me Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Here is such patcherie, such iugling, and such knauery: all the argument is a whore, and a Cuckold, a good quarrell to draw emulous factions, & bleed to death vpon.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Where is Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Within his tent, but ill disposd my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let it be knowne to him; ●hat we are heere,
He sate, our messengers and we lay by,
Our appertainings, visiting of him
Let him be told so, least perchance he thinke,
We dare not moue the question of our place,
Or know not what we are.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: I shall say so to him.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: We saw him at the opening of his tent,
Hee i● not sick.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p:
Yes Lion sick, sick of proud heart, you may call it
melancholy if you will fauour the man. But by my head 'tis pride: but why, why, let him shew vs a cause?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What mooues Aiax thus to bay at him?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Achillis hath inuegled his foole from him,

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Who Thersites?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: He.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Then will Aiax lack matter, if he haue lost his argument.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: No you see he is his argument, that has his argument Achilles.

sp.speaker: Nes.
sp.p: All the better, their fraction is more our wish then their faction, but it was a strong composure a foole could disunite.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily vnty.
Heere comes Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: No Achilles with him.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: The Elephant hath ioynts, but none for courtesie,
His legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: Achilles bids me say he is much sorry,
If any thing more then your sport and pleasure
Did mooue your greatnesse, and this noble state,
To call vpon him. He hopes it is no other
But for your health, and your disgestion sake,
An after dinners breath.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Heere you Patroclus:
We are too well acqu●inted with these answers,
But his cuasion winged thus swift with scorne,
Cannot out-flie our apprehensions,
Much attribute he hath, and much the reason
Why we ascribe it to him. Yet all his vertues,
Not vertuously on his owne part beheld,
Doe in our eyes begin to lose their glosse,
Yea like faire fruite in an vnholsome dish,
Are like to rott vntasted. Go and tell him,
We come to speake with him, and you shall not winne,
If you do say, we thinke him ouer-proud
And vnder-honest, in selfe assumption greater
Then in the note of iudgement. And worthier then himselfe
Heere tend the sauage strangenesse he puts on
Disguise, the holy strength of their commaund,
And vender-write in an obseruing kinde,
His humorous predominance: yea watch
His course, and time, his ebbs and flowes, and if
The passage, and wholest came of his commeacement,
Rode on his tide Goe tell him this, and adde,
That if he ouer-hold his price so much,
Weele ' none of him, But let him like an engine,
Not portable, lye vnder this report.
Bring action hither, this cannot go to warre,
A stirring dwarfe we doe allowance giue,
Before a sleeping gyant. Tell him so.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: I shall, and bring his answer presently.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: In second voyce weele not be satisfied,
We come to speake with him: Vlisses entertaine.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: What is he more then another.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: No more then what he thinkes he is.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Is he so much: doe you not thinke he thinkes himselfe a better man then I am?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: No question.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: No noble Aiax, you are as strong, as valiant, as wife, no lesse noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.p: Why should a man be proud? how doth pride grow? I know not what pride is.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Your minde is the cleerer, and your vertues the fairer, hee that is proud eates vp him-selfe: Pride is his owne glasse, his owne trumpet, his owne chronicle, and what euer praises it selfe but in the deed, deuoures the deed in the praise.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: I do hate a proud man, as I do hate the ingendring of Toades.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: And yet he loues himselfe, i●t not strange?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: Achilles will not to the field to morrow.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Whats his excuse?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: He doth r●lye on none.
But carries on the streame of his dispose,
Without obseruance, or respect of any,
In will peculiar, and in selfe admission.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Why will he not vpon our faire request,
Vntent his person, and share th ayre with vs.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Things small as nothing, for requests sake onely,
He makes important possest he is with greatnesse,
And speakes not to himselfe but with a pride,
That quarrels at selfe breath. Imagind worth,
Holds in his bloud such swolne and hott discurse,
That twixt his mentall and his actiue parts,
Kingdom ● Achilles in commotion rages,
And batters downe himselfe. What should I say,
He is so plaguie proud, that the death tokens of it,
Crie no recouerie.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Let Aiax go to him,
Deere Lord, go you, and greete him in his tent,
'Tis said he holds you well, and will be lead,
At your request 〈◊〉 from himselfe.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: O Agamemnon let it not be so,
Weele consecrate the steps that Aiax makes,
When they go from Achilles: shall the proud Lord
That ba●ts his arrogance with his own●seame,
And neuer suffe●s matter of the world
Enter his thoughts, 〈◊〉 such as doth reuolue,
And ●uminate him-selfe: shall he be worsh●pt,
Of that we hold an idoll more then hee,
No● this thrice worthy and right valiant Lord,
Shall not so staule his palme nob●y acquird,
Nor by my will aslubiugate his merit,
As amply liked as Achilles is by going to Achilles,
That were to enlard his fat already pride,
And adde more coles to Cancer when he burnes,
With entertaining great Hiperi●●,
This Lord go to him. Iupiter forbid,
And sa● in thunder Achilles go to him.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: O this is well, he rubs the vaine of him.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: And how his silence drinkes vp his applause,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: If I go to him: with my armed fist ile push him ore the ●a●e.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: O no, you shall not goe,

sp.speaker: Aia.
sp.l: And he be proud with me, Ile phe●e his pride,
Let me go● to him.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: Not for the worth that hangs vpon our quarrell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: A paltry insolent fellow.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: How he describes him selfe.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Can he not be sociable.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: The Rauen chides blacknesse.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: Ile tell his humorous bloud.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.p: Hee wilbe the phisition, that should bee the pacient.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: And all men were of my minde.

sp.speaker: Vliss
sp.p: Wit would bee out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: A should not beare it so, a should eate swords first? shall pride carry it?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: And t●o●od yow'd carry halfe.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: A would haue ten shares. I will kneade him, Ile make him supple he's not yet through warme?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: Force him with praiers poure in, poure, his ambition is d●ie.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: My Lord you feed to much on this dislike,

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.p: Our noble generall do not do so?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

sp.speaker: Vliss:
sp.l: Why tis this naming of him do's him harme,
H re is a man but tis before his face, I wilbe silent.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Wherefore should you so?
He is not emulous as Achilles is.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Know the whole world hee is as valiant—

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.p: A hoarson dog that shall palter with vs thus, would he were a Troyan?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: What a vice were it in Aiax now:

sp.speaker: Vliss:
sp.l: If hee were proude.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Or couetous of praise.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: I or surly borne.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Or strange or selfe affected.

sp.speaker: Vliss:
sp.l: Thank the heauens Lord, thou art of sweet composure
Praise him that gat thee, shee that gaue thee suck:
Fam'd be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature,
Thrice fam'd beyond all thy erudition:
But hee that disciplind thine armes to fight,
Let Mars diuide eternity in twaine,
And giue him halfe, and for thy vigour?
Bull-bearing Mil● his addition yeeld,
To sinowy Aiax, I will not praise thy wisdome,
Which like a boord: a pale, a shore confines
This spacious and dilated parts, here's Nestor,
Instructed by the antiqua●y times:
He must, he is, he cannot but be wise,
But pardon father Nestor were your daies
As greene as Aiax, and your braine so temper'd,
You should not haue the emynence of him,
But be as Aiax.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Shall I call you father?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I my good Sonne.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Be ruld by him Lord Aiax.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: There is no tarrying here the Hart Achilles,
Keepes thicket, please it our great generall,
To call together all his state of warre,
Fresh Kings are come to Troy, To morrow
We must with all our maine of power stand fast,
And here's a Lord come Knights from East to West
And call their flower, Aiax shall cope the best.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Go we to counsell, let Achilles sleepe,
Light boates saile swift, though greater hulkes draw deepe.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Friend you, pray you a word, doe you not follow the yong Lord Paris.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I sir when he goes before mee.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You depend vpon him I meane.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sir I do depend vpon the Lord.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You depend vpon a notable gentleman I must needs praise him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The Lord be praized?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You know me? ●oe you not?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Faith sir superficially.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Friend know mee better, I am the Lord Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I hope I shall know your honour better?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do desire it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are in the state of grace?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Grace? not so friend, honour and Lordship are my titles, what musicke is this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I do but partly know sir, it is musick in partes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Know you the musiciars?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Wholy sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Who play they to?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To the hearers sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: At whose pleasure friend?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: At mine sir, and theirs that loue musicke,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Command I meane:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who shall I command sir?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Friend we vnderstand not one another, I am to courtly and thou to cunning, at whose request do these men play?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That's to't indeed sir? marry sir, at the request of Paris my Lord, who is there in person, with him the mortall Venus, the heart bloud of beauty, loues inuisible soule:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Who my cozen Cressida,

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: No sir, Hellen, could not you finde out that by her attributes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: It should seeme fellow thou hast not seene the Lady Cressid I come to speake with Paris, from the Prince Troylus. I will make a complemental● assault vpon, him for my businesse seeth's.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sodden businesse, theirs a stew'd phrase indeed.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Faire be to you my Lord, and to al this faire company, faire desires in all faire measure fairlie guide them, especially to you faire Queene faire thoughts be your faire pillow.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Dere Lord you are full of faire words:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You speake your faire pleasure sweet Queene,
Faire Prince here is good broken musicke.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: You haue broke it cozen: and by my life you shall make it whole againe, you shall peece it out with a peece of your performance.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.p: he is full of harmony:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Truely Lady no:

sp.speaker: Hel:
sp.p: O sir:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p: Rude in sooth, in good sooth very rude.

sp.speaker: Paris:
sp.p: Well said my Lord, well, you say so in fits:

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I haue businesse to my Lord deere Queene? my Lord will you vouchsafe me a word.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Nay this shall not hedge vs out, weele here you sing ●ertain●ly:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.p:
Well sweete Queene you are pleasant with mee, but,
marry thus my Lord my deere Lord, and most esteemed friend your brother Troylus.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: My Lord Pandarus hony sweet Lord,

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Go too sweet Queene, go to?
Comends himselfe most affectionatly to you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: You shall not bob vs out of our melody,
If you do our melancholy vpon your head.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sweet Queene, sweet Queene, thats a sweet Queene
I faith—

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And to make a sweet Lady sad is a sower offence.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Nay that shall not serue your turne, that shall it not in truth la? Nay I care not for such words, no, no. And my Lord hee desires you that if the King cal for him at super. You will make his excuse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My Lord Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What saies my sweete Queenem, y very very sweet Queene?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What exploit's in hand, where suppes he to night?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Nay but my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: What saies my sweet Queene? my cozen will fall out with you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: You must not know where he sups.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ile lay my life with my disposer Cresseida.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No, no? no such matter you are wide, come your disposer is sicke.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Well ile makes excuse?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I good my Lord, why should you say Cresseida, no, your disposers sick.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I spie?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You spy? what doe you spie? come, giue mee an instrument now sweete Queene:

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Why this is kindely done?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My Neece is horribly in loue with a thing you haue sweete Queene.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Shee shall haue it my Lord, if it bee not my Lord Paris.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Hee? ●o? sheele none of him, they two are tawine.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Falling in after falling out may make them three.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Come, come, Ile heare no more of this, Ile sing you a song now.

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p: I, I, prethee, now by my troth sweet lad thou haste a fine fore-head.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: I you may, you may.

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p: Let thy song be loue: this loue will vndoe vs all. Oh Cupid, Cupid, Cupid.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Loue? I that it shall yfaith.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: I good now loue, loue, nothing but loue.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: Loue, loue, nothing but loue, still loue still more
For o loues bow. Shoots Bucke and Doe.
The shafts confound not that it wounds
But ticles still the sore:
These louers cry, o● ho they dye,
Yet that which seemes the wound to kill,
Doth turne oh ho, to ha ha he,
So dying loue liues still,
O ho a while, but ha ha ha,
O ho grones out for ha ha ha— hey ho,

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p: In loue I faith to the very tip of the nose.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: He eates nothing but doues loue, and that breeds hot blood, and hot bloud begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deedes, and hot deeds is loue.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Is this the generation of loue: hot bloud hot thoughts and hot deedes, why they are vipers, is loue a generation of vipers:
sp.l: Sweete Lord whose a field to day?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Anthenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. I would faine haue arm'd to day, but my Nell would not haue it so.
sp.l: How chance my brother Troylus went not?

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.p: He hangs the lippe at something, you know al Lord Pandarus.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Not I hony sweete Queene, I long to heare how they sped to day:
sp.l: Youle remember your brothers excuse?

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.p: To a hayre.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Farewell sweete Queene.

sp.speaker: Hell.
sp.l: Commend me to your neece.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: I will sweet Queene.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: Their come from the field: let vs to Priames Hall
To greete the warriers. Sweet Hellen I must woe you,
To helpe v●-arme our Hector: his stubborne bucle●
With this your white enchaunting fingers toucht;
Shall more obey then to the edge of steele▪
Or force of Greekish sinewes: you shall do more
Then all the Hand Kinges, disarme great Hector▪

sp.speaker: Hell:
sp.l: Twil make vs proud to be his seruant Paris●
Yea what he shall receiue of vs in duty,
Giues vs more palme in beauty then we haue.
Yea ouer shines our selfe.

sp.speaker: Par:
sp.l: Sweet above thought I loue her?

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: How now wher's thy maister, at my Cousin Cress●das?

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.l: No sir stayes for you to conduct him thether.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: O heere he comes● how now, how now?

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Sirra walke off.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: Haue you seene my Cousine?

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: No Pandarus, I stalke about her dor●
Like to a strange soule vpon the Stigian banke●
Staying for waftage. O be thou my Char●n.
And giue me swift transportance to these fieldes,
Where I may wallow in the lilly beds
Propos●d for the deseruer. O gentle Pandar,
From Cupids shoulder plucke his painted wings,
And flye with me to Cressid.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.l: Walke heere ith'Orchard, Ile bring her straight▪

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: I am giddy; expectation whirles me round,
Th'ymaginary relish is so sweete,
That it inchaunts my sence: what will it be
When that the wa●ry pallats ●aste indeed
Loues thrice repured Nectar? Death I feare me
Sounding distruction, or some ioy to fyne,
To subtill, potent, tun'd to sharp in sweetnesse
For the capacity of my ruder powers;
I feare it much, and I doe feare beside●
That I shall loose distinction in my ioyes
As doth a battaile, when they charge on heapes
The enemy flying.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Shees making her ready, sheele come straight, you must be witty now, she does so blush, and fetches her wind so short as if shee were fraid with a spirite: Ile fetch her; it is the pre●●iest villaine, she fetches her breath as short as a new ●ane sparrow.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Euen such a passion doth imbrace my bosome,
My heart beats thicker then a ●eauorous pulse,
And all my powers do their bestowing loose
Like vassalage at vnwares encountring the eye of maiesty.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Come, come, what need you blush?
sp.p: Shames a babie; heere shee is now, sweare the othes now to her that you haue sworne to me: what are you gone againe, you must be watch●●re you be made ●ame, must you? come your waies come your waies, and you draw backward weele put you i●h filles: why doe you not speake to her. Come draw this curtaine, and lets see your picture; alasse the day? how loath you are to offend day light; and twere darke youl close sooner: so so, rub on and kisse the mistresse; how now a kisse in fee-fa●●e: build there Carpenter▪ the ayre is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you. The fa●lcon, as the tercell: for all the ducks i●h riuer: go too, go too.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.p: You haue bereft me of all wordes Lady.

sp.speaker: Pand:
sp.p: Words pay no debts; giue her deeds: but sheele bereaue you ath' deeds too if she call your acti●ity in question: what billing again: heeres in witnesse whereof the parties interchangeably. Come in come in Ile go get a fire?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will you walke in my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: O Cressed how often haue I wisht me thus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Wish● my Lord? the gods graunt? O my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: What should they graunt? what makes this pretty abruption: what to cur●ou● dreg espies my sweete lady in the fountaine of our loue?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: More dregs then water if my teares haue eyes.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Feares make diuels of Cherubins, they neuer see truly.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: B●ind feare that seeing reason leads, finds safer footing, then blind reason, stumbling without feare: to feare the worst oft cures the worse.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: O let my Lady apprechend no feare,
In all Cupids pageant there is presented no monster.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Nor nothing monstrous neither.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Nothing but our vndertakings, when wee vow 〈◊〉 weepe seas, liue in fire, eate rockes, ●ame Tygers, thinking it harder for our mistresse to deuise impo●ition ynough then for vs to vndergoe any difficulty imposed.—
This the monstruosity in loue Lady, that the will is infinite and the execution confind, that the desire is boundlesse, and the act a slaue to lymite.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: They say all louers sweare more performance then they are able, and yet reserue an ability that they neuer performe: vowing more then the perfection of ten: and discharging lesse then the tenth part of one. They that haue the voyce of Lyons, and the act of Hares are they not monsters?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: Are there such: such are not we; Praise vs as wee are tasted, allow vs as we proue: our head shall goe bare till merit louer part no affection in reuersion shall haue a praise in present: we will not name desert before his birth, and being borne, his addition shall bee humble: few wordes to faire faith. Troylus shall be such to Cressid, as what enuy can say worst shall bee a mocke for his truth, and what truth can speake truest not truer then Troylus.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Will you walke in my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: What blushing still, haue you not done talking ye●●

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Well Vncle what folly I commit I dedicate to you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: I thanke you for that, if my Lord gette a boy of you, youle giue him me: be true to my Lord, if he ●●inch chide me for it.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.p: You know now your hostages, your Vncles word and my firme faith.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p:
