Nay Ile giue my word for her too: our kindred though they be long ere they bee woed▪ they are constant
being wonne, they are burres I can tell you, theyle sticke where they are throwne.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Bouldnesse comes to me now and brings me heart: Prince Troylus I haue loued you night and day, for many weary moneths.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Why was my Cressid then so hard to wy●?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Hard to seeme wonne: but I was wonne my Lord
With the first glance; that euer pardon me
If I confesse much you will play the tyrant,
I loue you now, but till now not so much
But I might maister it; in faith I lye,
My thoughts were like vnbrideled children grone
Too headstrong for their mother: see wee fooles,
Why haue I blab●d: ●ho shall be ●rue to vs
When we a●e so vnsecret to our selues.
But though I loue'd you well, I woed you not,
And yet good faith I wisht my selfe a man;
Or that we women had mens priuiledge
Of speaking first. Sweete bid me hold my tongue,
For in this rapture I shall surely speake
The thing I shall repent: see see your sylence
Comming in dumbnesse, from my weaknesse drawes
My very soule of councell. Stop my mouth.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: And shall, albeit sweet musique issues thence.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Pretty yfaith.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: My Lord I doe beseech you pardon me,
Twas not my purpose thus to begge a kisse:
I am asham'd; O Heauens what haue I done ●
For this time will I take my leaue my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Your leaue sweete Cressid:

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.l: Leaue: and you take leaue till to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Pray you content you.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: What offends you Lady?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: sir mine own company.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: You cannot shun your selfe.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Let me goe and try:
I haue a kind of selfe recids with you:
But an vnkinde selfe, that it selfe will leaue,
To be anothers ●oole. I would be gone:
Where is my wit? I know not what I speake,

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Well know they what they speake, that speake so wisely,

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Perchance my Lord I show more craft then loue,
And fell so roundly to a large confession.
To angle for your thoughts, but you are wise,
Or else you loue not: for to be wise and loue,
Exceeds mans might that dwells with gods aboue,

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: O that I thought it could be in a woman.
As if it can I will presume in you,
To feed for age her lampe and flames of loue.
To keepe her constancy in pligbt and youth.
Out-liuing beauties outward, with a mind,
That doth renew swifter then blood decays,
Or that persuasion could but thus conuince me▪
That my integrity and truth to you,
Might be affronted with the match and waight,
O● such a winnowed purity in loue,
How were I then vp-lifted! but alasse,
I am as true as truths simplicity,
And simpler then the infancy of truth.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In that ile war with you,

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Overtuous fight,
When right with right warres who sha'be most right,
True sw●ins in loue shall in the world to come
Approue their trueth by Troylus, when their times,
Full of protest, of oath and big compare,
Wants ●imele's truth tyrd with iteration.
As true as steele, as plantage to the moone.
As sunne to day: as vnckle to her mate,
As Iron to Adamant: as Earth to th' Center,
After all comparisons of truth.
(As truths anthentique author to be cited)
As ●rue as Troylus, shall croune vp the verse,
And sancti●ie the nombers,

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Prophet may you bee,
If I bee fal●e or swarue a hayre from truth,
When time is ould or hath forgot it selfe,
When water drops haue worne the stones of Troy,
And blind obliuion swallowd Citties vp.
And mighty states character-les are grated,
To dusty nothing, yet let memory,
From falce to falce among falce mayds in loue,
Vpbraid my falcehood, when th'haue said as falce,
As ayre, as water, wind or sandy earth,
As Fox to Lambe; or Wolfeto Heifers Calfe,
Pard to the Hind, or stepdame to her Sonne▪
Yea let them say to sticke the heart of falsehood,
As false as Cressid.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Go to a bargaine made, scale it, seale it ile bee the witnes here I hold your hand, here my Cozens, if euer you proue false one, to another since I haue taken such paine to bring you together let all pittifull goers between be cald to the worlds end after my name, call them all Panders, let all constant men be Troylusses all fal●e woemen Cressids, and all brokers betweene panders; say Amen.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.p: Amen▪

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Amen.
Wherevpon I will shew you a Chamber, which bed because it shall not speake of your prety encounters presse it to death; away.
sp.l: And Cupid grant all tong-tide maydens here,
Bed, chamber, Pander to prouide this geere.

div.stage: Enter Vlisses, Diomed, Nestor, Agamem, Chal●as.

sp.speaker: Cal
sp.l: Now Princes for the seruice I haue done,
Th'aduantage of the time prompts me aloud,
To call for recompence: appere it to mind,
That through the sight I beare in things to loue,
I haue abandond Troy, left my possession,
Incurd a traytors name, exposd my selfe,
From certaine and possest conueniences,
To doubtfull fortunes sequestring from me all,
That time acq●aintance, custome and condition,
Made ●ame, and most familiar to my nature:
And here to doe you seruice am become,
As new into the world, strange, vnacquainted.
I do beseech you as in way of tast,
To giue me now a little benefit.
Out of those many registred in promise,
Which you say liue to come in my behalfe●

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What wouldst thou of 〈◊〉 Troian? make demand?

sp.speaker: Calc.
sp.l: You haue a Troian prisoner cald Aut●●or▪
Yesterday tooke, Troy holds him very deere.
Of● haue you (often haue you thankes therefore)
Desird my Cressed in right great exchange.
Whom Troy hath still deni'd, but this Auth●●●r,
I know is such a wrest in their affaires:
That their nego●iations all must slacke,
Wan●ing his mannage and they will almost,
Giue v●▪ a Prince of blood a Sonne of Prya●,
In change of him. Let him be sent great Princes,
And he shall buy my daughter: and her presence,
Shall quite strike of all seruice I haue done,
In most accepted paine.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Let Diomedes beare him,
And bring vs Cressid hither, Calcas shall haue
What he requests of vs▪ good Diomed
Furnish you farely for this enterchange,
Withall bring word If Hector will to morrow,
Bee answered in his challenge. Aiax is ready.

sp.speaker: Di●.
sp.l: This shall I vndertake, and tis a bu●then
Which I am proud to beare.

div.stage: Achilles and Patro stand in their sent.

sp.speaker: Vli.
sp.l: Achilles stands its entrance of his tent,
Please it our generall passe strangely by him:
As if he were forgot, and princes all,
●ay negligent and looke regard vpon him,
I will come last, tis like heele question mee.
Why such vnpaulsiue eyes are bent? why ●urnd on him,
If so I haue derision medecinable,
To vse betweene your strangnes and his pride,
Which his owne will shall haue desire to drinke▪
It may doe good, pride hath no other glasse,
To show it selfe but pride: for supple knees,
Feed arrogance and are the proud mans fees,

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Weele execute your purpose and put on,
A forme of strangnesse as ●e 〈◊〉 along▪
So do each Lord, and either greet him no●
Or els disdaynf●lly, which shall shake him more:
Then if not lookt on. I will lead the way.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What comes the generall to speake with mee?
You know my minde Ile fight no more 'gainst Troy:

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What saies Achilles would he ought with vs?

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Would you my Lord ought with the generall.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord:

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: The bet●es▪

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Good day, good day:

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: How do you? how do you?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What do's the C●●kould scorne me●

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: How now Patroclus?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Good morrow Aiax?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Ha:

sp.speaker: Achil
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I and good next day too.

sp.speaker: Ac●.
sp.l: What meane these fellowes know they not Achilles?

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: They passe by strangely: they were vs'd to bend,
To send their smiles before them to Achilles:
To come as humbly as they vsd to creep, to holy a●ltars:

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What am I poore of late?
Tis certaine, greatnesse once falne out with fortune,
Must fall out with men to, what the declin'd is,
He shall as soone reade in the eyes of others
As feele in his owne fall: for men like butter-flies,
Shew not their mealy wings but to the Summer,
And not a m m for being simply man,
Hath any honour, but honour for those honours
That are without him, as place, ritches, and fauour,
Prizes of accident as oft as merit
Which when they fall as being slipery standers,
The loue that lean'd on them as slipery too,
Doth one pluck downe another, and together, die in the ●all,
But tis not so with mee,
Fortune and I are friends, I do enioy:
At ample point all that I did possesse,
Saue these mens lookes, who do me thinkes finde out:
Some thing not worth in me such ritch beholding,
As they haue often giuen. Here is Vlisses
Ile interrupt his reading, how now Vlisses?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Now great Thetis Sonne.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What are you reading?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: A strange fellow here,
Writes me that man, how derely euer parted:
How much in hauing or without or in
Cannot, make bost to haue that which he hath,
Nor feeles not what he owes but by reflection●
As when his vertues ayming vpon others,
Heate them and they retort that heate againe.
To the first giuers.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: This is not strange Vlisses,
The beauty that is borne here in the face:
The bearer knowes not▪ but commends it selfe,
To others eyes, nor doth the eye it selfe
That most pure spirit of sence, behold it selfe
Not going from it selfe: but eye to eye opposed,
Sallutes each other, with each others forme▪
For speculation turnes not to it selfe,
Till it hath trauel'd and is married there?
Where it may see it selfe: this is not strange at all.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: I do not straine at the position,
It is familiar, but at the authors drift,
Who in his circumstance expressly proo●es,
That no man is the Lord of any thing:
Though in and of him there be much con●isting,
Till he communicate his parts to others,
Nor doth hee of himselfe know them for aught:
Till he behold them formed in the applause.
Where th'are extended: who like an arch reuerb'rate
The voice againe or like a gate of steele:
●ronting the Sunne▪ receiues and renders back
His figure and his heate. I was much rap't i● this,
And apprehended here immediately,
Th'vnknowne Aiax, heauens what a man is there?
A very horse, that has he knowes not what
Nature what things there are.
Most obiect in regard, and deere in vse,
What things againe most deere in the esteeme:
And poore in worth, now shall we see to morrow,
An act that very chance doth throw vpon him
Aiax renown'd? O heauens what some men doe,
While some men leaue to doe.
How some men creepe in skittish fortunes hall,
Whiles others play the Ideo●● in her eyes,
How one man eates into anothers pride,
While pride is fasting in his w●ntonesse.
To see these Grecian Lords, why euen already:
They clap the lubber Aiax on the shoulder
As if his foote were one braue Hectors b●est,
And great Troy shriking.

sp.speaker: Ach●ll.
sp.l: I doe beleeue it,
For they past by me as misers do by beggars,
Neither gaue to me good word nor looke:
What are my deeds forgot?

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Time hath (my Lord) a wallet at his back,
Wherein he puts almes for obliuion:
A great siz'd monster of ingratitudes,
Those scraps are good deeds past,
Which are deuour'd as fast as they are made,
Forgot as soone as done, perseuerance deere my Lord▪
Keepes honour bright, to haue done, is to hang▪
Quite out of fashion like a ru●ty male,
In monumentall mockry? take the instant way,
For honour trauells in a straight so narrow:
Where on but goes a brest, keepe then the path
For emulation hath a thousand Sonnes,
That one by one pursue, if you giue way,
Or turne a side from the direct forth right:
Like to an entred tide they all rush by,
And leaue you him, most, then what they do in present:
Though lesse then yours in passe, must ore top yours.
For time is like a fashionable hoast,
That slightly shakes his parting gu●st by th'hand,
And with his armes out-stretcht as he would flie,
Graspes in the comme●: the welcome euer smiles,
And farewell goes out sighing. Let not vertue seeke,
Remu●eration for the thing it was. For beauty, wit,
High birth, vigor of bone, desert in seruic●●
Loue, friendship, charity, are subiects al,
To enuious and calumniati g●●me,
One touch of nature makes the whole world kin,
That all with one consent praise new-borne ga●●es,
Though they are made and moulded of things past,
And goe to dust, that is a little guilt,
More laud then guilt o●e-dusted.
The present eye praises the present obiect.
Then maruell not ●hou great and complet man,
That all the Greekes begin to worship Aiax;
Since things in mo●ion sooner catch the eye,
That what stirs not. The ●rie went once on thee,
And still it might, and yet it may againe,
If thou wouldst not entombe thy selfe aliue,
And case ●●y reputation in thy tent.
Whose glorious deeds but in ●●ese fi●lds of late,
Made emulous missions mongst the gods them selues,
And draue great Mars to faction.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Of this my priuacie,
I haue strong reasons.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: But gainst your priuacie,
The reasons are more potent and heroycall:
Tis knowne Ach●●●es that you are in loue
With one of Priams daughters.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: H●●? knowne.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Is that a wonder:
The prouidence th●●● in 〈…〉 ●,
Knowes almost euery thing,
Findes bo●●om in the vncomprehens●●e depth,
Keepes place with thought and almost like the gods,
Do thoughts vn●aile in their ●umbe 〈◊〉
There is a mysterie (with whom relation
Durst neuer meddle) in the soule of state,
Which hath an operation more diuine,
Then breath or pen can giue expressure to:
All the commerse that you haue had with Troy,
As perfectly is ours, as yours my Lord,
And better would it fitt, Achilles much,
To throw downe Hector then Polixena.
But it must grieue young Pir●●s now at home,
When fame shall in our Ilands sound her trumpe,
And all the Greekish girles shall tripping sing,
Great Hectors sister did Achilles winne,
But our great Aiax brauely beate downe him:
Farewell my Lord: I as your louer speake,
The foole slides ore the Ice that you should breake.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: To this effect Achilles haue I moou'd you,
A woman impudent and mannish growne,
Is not more loth'd then an effeminate man
In time of action: I stand condemnd for this
They thinke my little stomack to the warre,
And your great loue to me, restraines you thus,
Sweete rouse your selfe, and the weake wanton Cupid,
Shall from your neck vnloose his amorous fould,
And like dew drop from the Lions mane,
Be shooke to ayre.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Shall Aiax fight with Hector.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: I and perhaps receiue much honor by him.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I see my reputation is at stake,
My fame is shrowdly gor'd.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: O then beware.
Those wounds heale ill, that men do give themselues,
Omission to doe what is necessary.
Seales a commission to a blanke of danger,
And danger like an ague subtly taints
Euen then when they sit idely in the sunne.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Go call Thersites hether sweet Patroclus,
Ile send the foole to Aiax, and desire him
Tinu●●e the Troyan lords after the combate,
To see vs heere vnarmd. I haue a womans longing,
An appe●tite that I am sick with-all,
To see great Hector in his weeds of peace,
To talke with him, and to behold his vis●ge,
Euen to my full of view. A labour sau'd.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.l: A wonder.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Aiax goes vp and downe the field asking for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: He must fight singly to morrow with Hector, and is so prophetically proud of an heroycall ●udgeling, that ●e raues in saying nothing.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Why a stalkes vp and downe like a peaco●k, ● stride and a stand: ruminates like an host●sse, that hath no Arithmatique but her braine to set downe her reckoning: bites his lip with a politique regarde, as who should say there were witte in this head and ●woo'd out: and so there is. But it lyes as coldly in him, 〈◊〉 fire in a sting, which will not show without knocking, the mans vndone for euer, for if Hector breake not his neck ith' combate, hee'le br●akt himselfe in vaine glory. Hee knowes not mee. I sayd good morrow Aiax: And hee replyes thankes Agamemnon. What thinke you of this man that takes mee for the Generall? Hees growne a very land-fish languagelesse, a monster, a plague of opinion, a man may weare it on both sides like a lether Ierkin.

sp.speaker: Achil
sp.p: Thou must be my Ambassador Thersites.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Who I: why heele answer no body: hee professes not answering, speaking is for beggers: he weares his tongue in's armes. I will put on his presence, let Patroclus make demands to me. You shall see the pageant of Aiax.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: To him Patroclus, tell him I humbly desire the valiant Aiax, to inuite the valorous Hector to come vnarm'd to my tent, and to procure safe-conduct for his person, of the mag●●animous and most illustriou● sixe or seauen times honour'd Captaine Generall of the armie. Aga●●em●e●, do this.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.p: Ioue blesse great Aiax.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Hum.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: I come from the worthy Achilles.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Who most humbly desires ●you to inuite Hector to his ●ent.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Hum?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: And to procure safe conduct from 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Agam●m●e●?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: What say you too't.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: God buy you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Your answer sir.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: If to morrow be a faire day, by a seuen of the clock it will goe one way or other, howsoeuer he shall pay for me ere hee ha's me.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.p: Your answer sir.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Fare yee well with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: No: but out of tune thus, What musick will be i● him, when Hector ha's knockt out his braines, I know not. But I am sure none, vnlesse the fidler Apollo get his sinnews to make Catlings on.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt beare a letter to him straight.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Let mee heare another to his horse, for thats the more capable crea●ure.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: My minde is troubled like a fountaine stird,
And I my selfe see not the bottome of it.

sp.speaker: Ther's.
sp.p: Would the fountaine of your minde were cleere Again●, that I might water an Asse at it, I had rather be a tick in a sheepe, then such a valiant ignorance.

div.stage: Enter at one doore Ae●ea●, at another Paris, Deiphobus, Ant●m●r, Diomed the Grecian with torches.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: See ho? who is that there?

sp.speaker: Dei●h.
sp.l: It is the Lord Aeneas.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Is the Prince there in person?
Had I so good occasion to lye long
As your prince Paris, nothing but heauenly businesse,
Should rob my bed mate of my company.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: That's my minde too? good morrow Lord Aene●●.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: A valiant Greeke Aene●● take his hand.
Witnesse the processe of your speech: wherein
You ●old how Dyomed a whole weeke by daies,
Did haunt you in the fie'd.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Health to you valiant sir,
During all question of the gentle truce:
But when I meete you arm'd, as black defiance,
As heart can thinke or courage execute.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: The one and other Diomed embraces,
Our blouds are now in calme, and so long helth:
Lul'd when contention, and occasion meete,
By Ioue ●le play the hunter for thy life,
With all my force, pursuite, and pollicy.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: And ●hou shalt hunt a Lyon that will flie,
With his face back-ward, in humane gentlenesse:
Welcome to Troy, now by A●ch●ses life,
Welcome indeed: by Venus hand I swere:
No man aliue can ●oue in such a sort,
The thing he meanes to kill, more excellently.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: We simpathize. 〈◊〉 let Aen●●● line
(If to my sword his fate be not the glory)
A thousand compleate courses of the Sunne,
But in mine emulous honor let him die:
With euery ioynt a wound and that to morrow—▪

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: We know each other well?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: We do and long to know each other worse.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This is the most despigh●●ull gentle greeting,
The noblest hatefull loue that ere I heard of, what bus●●nesse
Lord so earely▪

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: I was sent for to the King? but why I know no●.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: His purpose meetes you▪ twas to bring this Greeke,
To Calcho's house, and there to render him:
For the enfreed Anthenor the faire Cressid,
Lets haue your company, or if you please,
Hast there before vs. I constantly beleeue,
(Or rather call my thought a certaine knowledge)
My brother Troylus ●●●ges there to night,
Roufe him and giue him note of our approch▪
With the whole quality wherefore:
I feare we shall be much vnwelcom●.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.p: That I assure you: Tr●yl●●h●d rather Troy were borne to Greece, then Cressied borne from Troy.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: There is no helpe.
The bitter disposition of the time will haue it so:
On Lord, weele follow you.

sp.speaker: Aeneas.
sp.l: Good morrow all.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: And tell me noble Diomed, faith tell me true,
Euen in soule of sound good fellowship,
Who in your thoughts, deserues faire Helen best,
My selfe, or Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Both ●like▪
Hee merits well to haue her that doth seeke her,
Not making any scruple of her ●oyle,
With such ● hell of paine, and world of charge.
And you as well to keepe her, that defend her,
Not pallating the ●afte of her dishonour
With such a costly losse of wealth and friends,
He like a puling Cuckold would drinke vp,
The legs and dregs of a flat tamed peece:
You like a le●cher out of whorish loynes,
Are pleasd to breed out your inheri●ors,
Both merits poyzd, each weighs nor lesse nor more,
But he as he, the h●●ui●r for a whore.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: You are too bitter to your country-woman▪

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Shees bitter to her country▪ heare me Paris,
For euery fal●e drop in her bawdy veines,
A Grecians life hath 〈◊〉 for euery scruple
Of her contaminated cartion waight,
A Troyan hath beene slaine. Since she could speake,
Shee hath not giuen so many good words breath,
As for her Greekes and Troyans suff●ed death.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: Faire Diomed you do as chapmen do,
Dispraise the thing that they d●●●●e to buy,
But we in silence hold this vertue well,
Weele not commend, what wee inte●d to sell. Heere lyes our way.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Deere, trouble not your selfe, the morne is colde.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Then sweet my Lord ile call mine vnckle downe,
Hee shall vnbolt the 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Trouble him not.
To bed to bed: sleepe kill those pri●ty eyes,
And giue as soft a●●achment to thy sences,
As infants empty of all thought.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Good morrow then.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: ●p●ithee now to bed.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Are you a weary of me?

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: O Cresseids! but that the bu●ie day,
Wak't by the Larke hath rouzd the ribald Crowes,
And dreaming night will hide our ioyes no longer,
I would not from thee.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Night hath beene too briefe.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: B●shrew the witch I with venemous wight● she stai●●●
As ●ediously as h●ll, But flies the graspes of loue,
With wings more momentary swift then thought,
You will catch colde and curse me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Prithee ●arry, you men will neuer tarry,
O foolish Cresseid▪ I might haue still held of,
And then you would haue tarried, Harke ther's one vp.

sp.speaker: Pand
sp.l: Whats all the door●● open heere▪

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: It is your Vncle.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: A pestilence on him: now will he be mocking:
I shall haue such a life.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How now, how now, how go maiden-heads,
Heere you maide, where's my cozin Cresseid?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Go hang your selfe▪ you n●ugh●y● mocking vncle▪
You bring me to doo— and th●●▪ you flou●e me to.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: To do what, to do what? let her say what,
What haue I brought you to doe?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Come, come▪ ●eshr●w your heart, youle ●●re be good, not suffer others.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Ha▪ ha: alas poore wretch: a poore chipochi●, hast not slept ●o night? would hee not (a naughty man) let it sleepe, a bug-beare take him.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Did not I tell you? would he were 〈…〉 ●,
Who's that 〈◊〉 doore, good vnckle go and s●e.
My Lord, come you againe into my chamber,
You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Come you are deceiued, I thinke of no such thing,
How earnestly they knock, pray you come in.
I would not for halfe Troy haue you seene here,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Who's there? what's the matter? will you beate downe the doore? How now, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.p: Good morrow Lord, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Who's there my Lord Aeneas: by my troth I knew you not: what newes with you so early?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Is not Prince Troylus heere?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Here, what should he do here?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Come he is here, my Lord, do not deny him,
It doth import him much to speake with me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Is he here say you▪ its more then I know ile be sworne For my owne part I came in late: what should hee doe here?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.p: Who, nay then! Come▪ come, youle do him wrong ere you are ware, youle be so true to him, ●o be false to him: Do not you know of him, but yet go fetch him hither, go.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: How now, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: My Lord, I scarce haue leisure to salute you,
My matter is so rash: there is at hand,
Paris your brother, and Deiphobus,
The Grecian Diomed, and our Anthenor
Deliuer'd to him, and forth-with,
Ere the first sacrifice, within this houre,
We must giue vp to Diomedes hand
The Lady Cresseida▪

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Is it so concluded?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: By Priam and the generall state of Troy,
They are at hand, and ready to effect ●t.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: How my atchiuement● mock me▪
I will go meete them: and my Lord Aeneas,
We met by chance, you did not finde me here.

sp.speaker: Aen
sp.l: Good, good, my lord, the sec●ets of neighbor Pand●
Haue not more guift in ●aciturnitie.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Ist possible: no sooner got but lost, the diuell ●ake Anthenor, the young Prince will go ●●adde, a plague vpon Anthenor. I would they had brok's neck.
How now? what'● the matter? who was heere?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Ah, ah!

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Why sigh you so profoundly, wher's my Lord? gone? tell me sweeet Vncle, whats the matter.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Would I were as deepe vnder the earth as I am aboue.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: O the Gods, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Pray thee get thee in: would thou hadst nere been bo●●e, I knew thou wouldest be his death. O poore Gentleman, a plague vpon Anthenor.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.p: Good vnckle; I beseech you on my knees, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: Thou must be gone wench, thou must be gone: thou art chang'd for Anthenor. Thou must to thy father and bee gone from Troylus, twill be his death, twill bee his bane, hee cannot beare it.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O you immortall Gods, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thou must.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I will not Vncle. I haue forgot my father,
I know no touch of consanguinitie,
No kinne, no loue, no bloud, ●o soule so neere me
As the sweete Troylus. O you gods diuine,
Make Cresseids name the very crowne of falsehood,
If euer she leaue Troyl●●. Time, force and death,
Do to this body what extreames you can:
But the strong base, and building of my loue,
Is as the very center of the earth,
Drawing all things to it. Ile go in and weepe.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Tea●e my bright haire, & scratch my praised cheekes,
Crack my cleare voyce with sobs, and breake my heart,
With sounding Troylus: I will not go from Troy.

div.stage: Enter Paris, Troyl. Aeneas, Deiphob, A●th. Diomedes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It is great morning, and the houre prefixt,
For her deliuery to this valiant Greeke,
Comes fast vpon: good my brother Troylus
Tell you the Lady what she is to doe,
And hast her to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Walke into her house,
Ile bring her to the Grecian presently:
And to his hand when I deliuer her,
Thinke it an altar, and thy brother Troylus
A priest there offring ●o it his owne heart.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: I know what tis to loue,
And would, as I shall pitty I could helpe:
Please you walke in my Lords?

sp.speaker: Pan:
sp.l: Be moderate, be moderate.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Why tell you me of moderation?
The greife i● fine, full, perfect that I taste;
And violenteth in a sence as strong
As that which causeth it, how can I moderate it?
If I could temporize with my affections,
Or brew it to a weake and coulder pallat,
The like alayment could I giue my griefe:
My loue admittes no qualifiing drosse,
No more my griefe in such a precious losse.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here, here, here he comes, a sweete ducks.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Oh Troylus, Troylus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What a paire of spectacles is here, let me embrace too, Oh heart, as the goodly saying is, Oh heart, heauy heart, why sighst thou without breaking: where hee answers againe, because thou canst not ease thy smart by friendshippe nor by speaking: there was neuer a 〈◊〉 ●ime. Let vs cast away nothing, for wee may liue to haue need of such a verse, We see it, we see it, how now lambs?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Cressid I loue thee in so strain'd a purity,
That the blest Gods as angry with my fancy:
More bright in zeale then the deuotion, which
Cold lippes blow ●o their di●●ies, take thee from me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Haue the Gods enuy?

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.l: I, I, I, I, tis to plaine a case.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: And is it true that I must go from Troy?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: A hatefull truth.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What and from Troylus to?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: From Troy, and Troylus▪

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And suddenly, where iniury of chance
Pu●s back, leaue taking▪ iussles roughly by:
All time of pause: rudely beguiles our lippes
Of all reioyndu●e: forcibly preuent●
Our lock't embras●●es, strangles our dere vowes,
euen in the birth of our owne laboring breath:
We two that with so many thousand sighes,
Did buy each other, must poorely sell our selues:
With the rude breuity, and discharge of one,
Iniurious time now with a robbers hast,
Cra●●'s his ●itch thee●'ry vp hee knowes not how.
As many farewells as be starres in heauen.
With distinct breath, and consignde kisses to them▪
He fumbles vp into a loose adewe:
And ska●ts vs with a single famisht kisse,
Distasted with the salt of broken teares.

sp.speaker: Aeneas
sp.l: within. My Lord is the ●ady ready?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Harke, you are call'd, some say the Geni●●
Cries so to him that instantly must die,
Bid them haue pacience she shall come anon.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Where are my teares raine to lay this winde, or my heart wilbe blowne vp by my throate.

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: I must then to the Grecians.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: No remedy?

sp.speaker: Cress.
sp.l: A wofull Cressid mongst the merry Greekes,
When shall we see againe.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Here mee loue? be thou but true of heart.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I true? how now? what wicked deme is this?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Nay we must vse expostulation kindely,
For it is parting from vs.
I speake not be thou true as fearing thee.
For I will throw my gloue to death himselfe,
That there is no macula●●on in thy heart:
But bee thou true say I to fashion in▪
My sequent protestation; bee ●hou true, and I will ●ee thee.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Oh you shalbe expos●d my Lord to dang●rs,
As infinite as imminent; but ile be ●rue,

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: And ile grow friend with danger, were this sleeue.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: And you this gloue, when shall I see you?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I will corrupt the Grecian centinells,
To giue thee nightly visitation, but yet be true.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Oh heauens be true againe?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Here why I speake it loud,
The Grecian youths are full of quality,
And swelling ore with arts and excercise:
How nouelty may moue, and parts with portion,
Alas a kinde of Godly iealousi●,
(Which I beseech you cal a vert●ous sinne,)
Makes me a feard.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Oh heauens you loue mee not!

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Die I a villaine then,
In this I do not call your faith in question:
So mainely as my merit. I cannot sing
Nor heele the high la●o●t, nor sweeten talke,
Nor play at subtill games, faire vertues all:
To which the Grecians are most prompt and preg●ane▪
But I can tell that in each grace of these▪
There lurkes a still, and dumb-discours●●e diuell
That tempts most cunningly, but be not tempted.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Do you thinke I will?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: No, but somthing may be done that we will not,
And sometimes weare diuells to our selues:
When we will tempt the frail●y of our powers,
Presuming on their changefull potency.

sp.speaker: Eneas
sp.l: within. Nay good my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come kisse, and let vs part.

sp.speaker: Paris
sp.l: within. Brother Troylus?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Good brother come you hither?
And bring Eneas and the Grecian with you▪

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: My Lord will you be true?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Who I, alas it is my vice, my fault,
Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion,
I with great truth catch mere simplicity,
Whilst ●ome with cunning guild their copper crownes,
With truth and plainesse I do were mine bare:
Feare not my truth, the morrall of my wit,
Is plaine and true? ther's all the reach of it,
Welcome sir Diomed, here is the Lady,
Which for Antenor we deliuer you.
At the port (Lord) Ile giue her to thy hand,
And by the way possesse thee what she is
Entreate her faire, and by my soule faire Greeke,
If ere thou stand at mercy of my sword:
Name Cressid, and thy life shalbe as safe,
As Priam is in Illion?

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Faire Ladie Cressid,
So please you saue the thankes this Prince expects:
The lustre in your eye, heauen in your cheeke,
Pleades your faire vsage, and to Diomed,
You shalbe mistres, and command him wholy.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Grecian thou do'st not vse me curteously,
To shame the seale of my petition to thee:
In praising her. I tell thee Lord of Greece,
She is as farre high soaring ore thy praises:
As thou vnworthy to be call'd her seruant,
I charge thee vse her well, euen for my charge:
For by the dreadfull Pluto, if thou dost not,
Though the great bulke Achilles be thy guard,
Ile cut thy throate.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Oh be not mou'd Prince Troylus,
Let me be priueledg'd by my place and message:
To be a speaker free? when I am hence,
Ile answer to my lust, and know you Lord
Ile nothing do on charge, to her owne worth,
Shee shalbe priz'd: but that you say be't so,
I speake it in my spirit and honour no.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come to the port Ile ●el thee Diomed,
This braue shall oft make thee to hide thy head,
Lady giue me your hand, and as we walke,
To our owne selues bend we our needfull talke.

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: Harke Hectors trumpet?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: How haue we spent this morning?
The Prince must thinke me ●ardy ●nd re●●isse,
That swore to ride before him to the field,

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Tis Troylus falte, come, come, to field with him.

div.stage: Enter Aiax armed, Achilles, Patroclus, Agam▪ Menelaus, Vlisses, Nester, Calcas. &c.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Here art thou in appointmen● fresh and faire,
Anticipating time. With starting courage,
Giue with thy trumpet a loude note to Troy
Thou dreadfull Aiax that the appauled aire,
May pearce the head of the great Comba●ant, and hale him hither.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Thou, trumpet, ther's my purse,
Now cracke thy lungs, and split thy brasen pipe:
Blow villaine, till thy sphered Bias cheeke,
Out-swell the collick of puft Aquilo●,
Come stretch thy chest, and let thy eyes spout bloud:
Thou blowest for Hector.

sp.speaker: Vliss
sp.l: No trumpet answers.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Tis but early daies.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is not yond Diomed with Calcas daughter.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Tis he, I ken the manner of his ga●e,
He rises on the too: that spirit of his
In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Is this the Lady Cressid?

sp.speaker: Diom
sp.l: Euen she.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Most deerely welcome to the Greekes sweete Lady.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Our generall doth salute you with a kisse.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.p: Yet is the kindnesse but perticular, twere better shee were kis● in general.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: And very courtly counsell. Ile beginne: so much for Nestor.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Ile take that winter from your lips faire Lady,
Achilles bids you welcome.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I had good argument for kissing once.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: But thats no argument for kissing now,
For thus pop't Paris in his hardiment,
And parted thus, you and your argument.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Oh deadly gall and theame of all our scomes,
For which we loose our heads to guild his homes.

sp.speaker: Patro.
sp.l: The first was ●ward● kisse this mine,
Patrolus kisses you.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Oh this is trim.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: Paris and I kisse euermore for him.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Ile haue my kisse sir? Lady by your leaue.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In kissing do you render or receiue.

sp.speaker: Patr.
sp.l: Both take and giue.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Ile make my match to liue,
The kisse you take is better then you giue: therefore no kisse.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Ile giue you boote, ile giue you three for one.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You are an od man giue euen or giue none.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: An odde man Lady, euery man is odde.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: No Paris is nor, for you know tis true,
That you are odde and he is euen with you.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: You fillip me a'th head.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: No ile be sworne.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: It were no match, your naile against his horne,
May I sweete Lady begge a kisse of you.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: I do desire it.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Why begge then.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Why then for Venus sake giue me a kisse▪
When Hellen is a maide againe and his—

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I am your debtor, claime it when tis due.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Neuers my day, and then a kisse of you.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Lady a word, ile bring you to your father.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: A woman of quick sence.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Fie, fie vpon her,
Ther●s language in her eye, her cheeke her lip,
Nay her foote speakes, her wanton spirits looke out
At euery ioynt and motiue of her body,
Oh these encounrerers so glib of tongue,
That giue a coasting welcome eroit comes,
And wide vnclapse the tables of their thoughts,
To euery ticklish reader, set them downe,
For sluttis● spoiles of op●●rtunity:
And daughters of the game.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The Troyans trumpet.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Yonder comes the troup.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Haile all the state of Greece: what shalbe done,
To him that victory commands, or doe you purpose,
A victor shalbe knowne, will you the knights
Shall to the edge of all extremity
Pursue each other, or shall they be diuided,
By any voice or order of the field, Hector bad aske?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Which way would Hector haue it?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: He cares not, heele obay conditions.

sp.speaker: Aga:
sp.l: Tis done like Hector, but securely done,
A little proudly, and great deale misprising:
The knight oppos'd.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: If not Achilles sir, what is your name?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: If not Achilles nothing:

sp.speaker: Ene:
sp.l: Therefore Achilles, but what ere know this,
In the extremity of great and little:
Valour and pride excell themselues in Hector
The one almost as infinite as all,
The other blanke as nothing, way him well.
And that which lookes like pride is curtesie,
This Aiax is halfe made of Hectors bloud,
In loue whereof, halfe Hector staies at home,
Halfe heart, halfe hand, halfe Hector comes to seeke:
This blended knight halfe Troyan, and halfe Greeke.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: A maiden battell then, Oh I perceiue you.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Here is sir Diomed? go gentle knight,
Stand by our Aiax. As you and Lord Eneas
Conse●t vpon the order of their fight,
So be it, either to the vttermost,
Or els a breath, the combatants being kin,
Halfe stints their strife, before their strokes begin.
Vlisses: what Troyan is that same that lookes so heauy?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: The yongest sonne of Priam, a true knight,
Not yet mature, yet match●esse firme of word,
Speaking deeds, and deedlesse in his tongue,
Not soone prouok't nor beeing 〈◊〉 soone calm'd,
His heart and hand both open and both free.
For what he has he giues, what thinkes he shewes,
Yet giues hee not till iudgement guide his bounty,
Nor dignifies an impare thought with breath;
Manly as Hector, but more dangerous,
For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
To tender obiects, but he in heate of action,
Is more vindicatiue then iealous loue.
They call him Troylus, and on him erect,
A second hope as fairely built as Hector:
Thus saies Aeneas ou● that knowes the youth,
Euen to his ynches: and with priuate soule
Did in great Illion thus translate him to me.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: They are in action.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Now Aiax hould thine owne.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Hector thou sleep'st awake thee.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: His blowes 〈◊〉 well: dispo'd, there Aiax.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: You must no more.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Princes enough so please you.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I am not warme yet, let vs fight againe.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: As Hector pleases.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Why then will I no more,
Thou art great Lord my fathers sisters Sonne,
A couzen german to great Prianss feede,
The obligation of our bloud for bids,
A gory emulation twixt vs twaine:
Were thy 〈◊〉 Greeke and Troyan so,
That thou couldst say this hand is Grecian all:
And this is Troyan, the sinnewes of this legge
All Greeke, and this all Troy: my mothers bloud,
Runnes on the dexter cheeke, and this sinister
Bounds in my fathers. By loue multipotent
Thou shouldst not beare from mee a Greekish member,
Wherein my sword had not impressure made.
But the iust Gods gainsay,
That any day thou borrowd'st from thy mother,
My sacred Aunt, should by my mortal sword,
Be drained. Let me embrace thee Aiax:
By him that thunders thou hast lusty aimes,
Hector would haue them fall vpon him thus.
Cozen all honor to thee.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: I thanke thee Hector,
Thou art to gentle, and too free a man,
I came to kill thee cozen, and beare hence,
A great addition earned in thy death▪

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Not Neoptslymus so mirable,
On whose bright crest, fame with her lowdst (O yes)
Cries, this is he, could promise to himselfe,
A thought of added honor, torne from Hector.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: There is expectance heere from both the sides,
What further you will do.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Weele answer it,
The issue is embracement, Aiax farewell.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: If I might in entreaties finde successe,
As seld I haue the chance, I would desire,
My famous cosin to our Grecian tents.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: Tis Agamemnous wish, and great Achilles
Doth long to see vnarm'd the valiant Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Aeneas call my brother Troylus to me.
And signifie this louing enterview
To the expectors of our Troyan part,
Desire them home. Giue me thy hand my Cozen.
I will go eate with thee, and see your Knights

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Great Agamemnon comes to meete vs heere.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: The worthiest of them, tell me name by name:
But for Achilles my owne searching eyes,
Shall finde him by his large and portly size.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Worthy all armes as welcome as to one,
That would be rid of such an enemy.
From heart of very heart, great Hector welcome.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I thanke thee most imperious Agamemnon.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: My well-fam'd Lord of Troy, no lesse to you.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Let me confirme my princely brothers greeting:
You brace of warlike brothers: welcome hether.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Who must we answer?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: The noble Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O you my Lord, by Mars his gauntlet thankes,
(Mock not thy affect, the vntraded earth)
Your quandrm wife sweares still by Venus gloue,
Shees well, but bad me not commend her to you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Name her not now sir, shee's a deadly theame.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O pardon, I offend.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I haue thou gallant Troyan seene thee oft,
Laboring for destiny, make cruell way,
Through rankes of Greekish youth, and I haue seene thee
As hot as Perseus, spurre thy Phrigian steed,
Despising many forfaits and subduments,
When thou hast hung th'aduanced sword ith'ayre,
Not letting it decline on the declined,
That I haue said to some my standers by,
Loe Iupiter is yonder dealing life.
And I haue seene thee pause, and take thy breath,
When that a ring of Greekes haue shrupd thee in,
Like an Olympian wrastling. This haue I seene,
But this thy countenance still lockt in steele,
I neuer saw till now: I knew thy grand-fire,
And once fought with him, he was a soldier good,
But by great Mars the Captaine of vs all,
Neuer like thee: O let an old man embrace thee,
And worthy warriour welcome to our tents.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Tis the old Nestor.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Let me embrace thee good old Chronide,
That hast so long walkt hand in hand with time,
Most reuerend Nestor, I am glad to claspe thee.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: I would my armes could match thee in contention.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I would they could.

sp.speaker: Nest.
sp.l: Ha? by this white beard Ide fight with thee to morrow.
Well, welcome, welcome, I haue seene the time.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: I wonder now how yonder Citty stands,
When we haue here her base and piller by vs?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I know your fauour lord Vlisses well,
Ah sir, there's many a Greeke and Troyan dead,
Since first I saw selfe and Diomed,
In Illion on your Greekish embassie.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Sir I foretold you then what would ensue,
My prophecie is but halfe his iourney yet,
For yonder walls that pertly front your towne,
You towers, whose wanton tops do busse the clouds,
Must kisse their owne feete.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I must not beleeue you.
There they stand yet, and modestly I thinke▪
The fall of euery Phrigian stone will cost,
A drop of Gree an bloud: the end crownes all,
And that old common arbitrator Time, will one day end it.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: So to him we leaue it.
Most gentle and most va●ant Hector, welcome:
After the Generall, I beseech you next
To feast with me, and see me at my tent.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I shall forestall thee lord Vlisses thou:
Now Hector I haue fed mine eyes on thee, (by ioint.
I haue with exact view peru●de thee Hector, & quoted ioynt by ioint.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Is this Achilles?

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I am Achilles.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Stand faire I pray thee, let me looke on thee,

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Behold thy fill.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Nay I haue done already.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Thou art too briefe, I will the second time,
As I would buie thee, view thee lim by lim,

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O like a booke of sport thou'lt read me ore:
But ther's more in me then thou,
Why doost thou so oppresse me with thine eye.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Tell me you heauens, in which part of his body
Shall I destroy him: whether there, or there, or there,
That I may giue the locall wound a name,
And make distinct the very breach, whereout
Hectors great spirit flew: answer me heauens.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: It would discredit the blest gods proud man,
To answer such a question: stand againe,
Thinkst thou to catch my life so pleasantly,
As to prenominate in nice coniecture,
Where thou 〈◊〉 hit me dead.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I tell thee yea.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Wert thou an Oracle to tell me so,
Ile not beleeue thee▪ Hence-forth gard thee well,
For Ile not kill thee there, nor there, no● there,
But by the forge that stichied Mars his helme.
Ile kill thee euery where, yea ore and ore.
You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag,
His insolence drawes folly from my lips,
But ile endeuour deeds to match these words,
Or may I neuer—

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Do not cha●e thee cozen.
And you Achilles, let these threats alone,
Till accident or purpose bring you too't,
You may haue euery day enough of Hector,
If you haue stomack, The generall state I feare,
Can scarce entreate you to be odde with him.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I pray you let vs see you in the field,
We haue had pelting warres since you refusd, the Grecians cause.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Doost thou entreate me Hector?
To morow do I meet thee fell as death: to night all friends.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thy hand vpon that match.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: First all you Peeres of Greece, go to my ●ent,
There in the full conuiue we: afterwards
As Hectors leisure, and your bounties shall
Concurre together, seuerally entreate him
To taste your bounties, let the trumpets blowe,
That this great souldier may his welcome know.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: My Lord Vlisses, tell me I beseech you,
In what place of the field doth Calcas keepe.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: At Menelaus tent, most princely Troylus:
There Diomed doth feast with him to night,
Who neither lookes vpon the heauen nor earth,
But giues all gaze, and bent of amorous view,
On the faire Cresseid.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Shall I sweete Lord be bound to you so much,
After we part from 〈◊〉 tent,
To bring me thether.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: You shall command me sir.
But gentle tell me of what honor was
This Cressids in Troy? had she no louer there
That wailes her absence?

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: O sir to such as bosting shew their skarres,
A mocke is due; will you walke on my Lord,
Shee was beloued my Lord, she is, and doth,
But still sweet loue is food for fortunes tooth.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: Ile heate his blood with greekish wine to night,
Which with my Cemitar ile cool to morrow,
Patroclus let vs feast him to the hight

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Here comes Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: How now thou curre of enuy.
Thou cru●ly batch of nature whats the news?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why thou picture of what thou seemest, and Idoll,
Of idiot w●rshippe●s▪ heer's a letter for thee.

sp.speaker: Ach.
sp.l: From whence fragment.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why thou full dish of foole from Troy,

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Who keeps the tent now.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The Surgeons box or the pacients wound.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Well said aduersity, and what needs this tricks,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Prithee be silent box I profit not by thy talke,
Thou art said to be Achilles male varlot,

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Male varlot you rogue whats that.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why his masculine whore, now the ro'ten diseases of the south, the guts griping ruptures: loades a grauell in the back, lethergies, could palsies, rawe eies, durtrott● liuers, whissing lungs, bladders full of impostume, Sciaticaes lime. kills ith' palme, incurable bone-ach, and the riueled ●ee simple of the tetter, take and take againe such preposterous discoueries.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Why thou damnable box of enuy thou what meanes thou to curse thus.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: do I curse thee.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Why no you ruinous but, you horson indistinguishable cur, no.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: No why art thou then exasperate, thou idle immaterial skein● of sleiue silke, thou greene sacenet flap for a sore eye, thou toslell of a prodigalls purse-thou ah how the poore world is pestred with such water flies, diminitiues of nature.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.l: Out gall.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Finch egge.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: My sweet Patroclus I am thwarted quite,
From my great purpose into morrowes battell,
Here is a letter from Queene 〈◊〉▪
A token from her daughter my faire loue
Both taxing me, and gaging me to keepe:
An oth that I haue sworne: I will not breake it,
Fall Greekes, fayle fame, honour or go or stay,
My maior vow lies here; this ile obay,
Come, come, Thersites help to trim my tent?
This night in banquetting must al be spent, away Patroclus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: With to much bloud, and to little braine, these two may run mad, but if with to much braine and to little bloud they do ile be a curer of mad-men, her's Agamemnon, an honest fellow inough, and one that loues quailes, but hee has not so much braine as eare-wax, and the goodly transformation of Inpiter there, his be the Bull, the primitiue starue, and oblique memorial of cuck-olds, a thrifty shooing-horue in a chaine at his bare legge, to what forme but that hee is, should wit larded with malice, and malice faced with witte, turne him to: to an Asse, were nothing hee is both Asse and Oxe to an Oxe were nothing, her's both Oxe and Asse, to be a day, a Moyle, a Cat, a Fichooke, a Tode, a Lezard, an Oule, a Puttock, or a Herring without a rowe. I would not care, but to bee Menelaus I would conspire against desteny, aske me what I would be, if I were not Thersites, for I care not to be the Louse of a Lazar, so I were not Menelaus— hey-day sprites and fires.

div.stage: Enter Agam: Vlisses, Nest: and Diomed with lights.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: We go wrong we goe wrong.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: No, yonder tis there where we see the lights.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I trouble you.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: No not a whit:

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Here comes himselfe to guide you.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Welcome braue Hector, welcome Princes all.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: So now faire Prince of Troy, I bid God night,
Aiax commands the guard to tend on you.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Thanks and good night to the Greekes generall.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Good night my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Good night sweet Lord Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Sweet draught, sweet quoth a, sweet sinke, sweet sure.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Good night and welcome both to those that go or tarry.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Good night.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Old Nector tarries, and you to Diomed.
Keepe Hector company an houre or two.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I cannot Lord, I haue important businesse,
The tide whereof is now, good night great Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Giue me your hand.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.p: Follow his torch, he goes to Calcas tent, ile keepe you company.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Sweet sir you honor me?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: And so good night.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Come, come, enter my tent.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: That same Diomede a false hearted roague, a most vniust knaue, I will no more trust him when hee leeres, then I will a serp●at when hee hisses, hee will spend his mouth and promise like brabler the 〈◊〉, but when he performes, Astronomers forett●● it, is 〈◊〉, there will come some change, the Some borrowe● of the Moone when Diomed keepes his word, I will rather leaue to see Hector then not to dog him, they say hee keepes a Troyan drab, and vses the traytor Calcas tent, Ile after— nothing but let chery all incontinent varlots.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What are you vp here 〈◊〉 speake?

sp.speaker: Chal.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: 〈◊〉, Chalc●s I thinke wher's your daughter?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: She comes to you.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Stand, where the torch may not disceuer vs.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Cressid comes forth to him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: How now my charge.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Now my sweet gardian, harke a word with you.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Yea so samiliar?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Shee will sing any man at first sight.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: And any man may sing her, if hee can take her Cliff, she's noted.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Will you remember?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Remember yes:

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Nay but do then and let your minde be coupled with your words.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: What shall she remember.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Lift?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Sweet hony Greeke tempt me no more to folly.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.l: Roguery.

sp.speaker: Dis.
sp.l: Naythen.

sp.speaker: Cress:
sp.l: Ile tell you what.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Fo, fo, come tell a pin you are forsworne.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: In faith I cannot, what would you haue me do?

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.l: A rugling tricke to be secretly open,

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: What did you sweare you would bestow on me?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: I prethee do not hold me to mine oath,
Bid me do any thing but that sweete Greeke.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Good night.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Hold patience.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: How now Troyan.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: No, no, good night Ile be your foole no more,

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Thy better must,

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Harke a word in your eare.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: O plague and madnesse!

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: You a●e moued Prince, let vs depart I pray
Least your displeasure should inlarge it selfe
To wrathfull tearmes, this place is dangerous:
The time right deadly, I beseech you goe.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Behold I pray you.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: Now good my Lord go off.
You flow to great distruction, come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: I prethee stay.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: You ●aue not patience, come.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: I pray you stay; by hell, and all hells tormen●▪
I will not speake a word.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: And so good night,

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Nay but you part in anger▪

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Doth that grieue thee, O withered truth.

sp.speaker: Vlis▪
sp.l: How now my Lord?

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: By loue I will be patient.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Gardian? why Greeke?

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Fo fo you palter.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: In faith I doe not, come hether once againe.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.p: You shake my Lord at something, will you goe. you wil break out.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: She stroakes his cheeke.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Nay stay, by Ioue I will not speake a word,
Therein betweene my will and all 〈◊〉
A guard of patience, stay a little while,

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: How the diuell Luxury with his fat rumpe and potato finger, tickles together; frye lechery frye.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Will you then?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: In faith I will lo, neuer trust me else.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Giue me some token for the surety of it.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Ile fetch you one.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: You haue sworne patience:

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Feare me not my Lord.
I will not be my selfe, not haue cognition
Of what I feele, I am all pa●ience:

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.l: Now the pledge, now, now, now.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Heere Diomed keepe this sleeue.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: O beauty where is thy faith▪

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: You looke vpon that sleeue behold it well,
Hee loued me (oh false wench) giu't me againe:

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Whose wast?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: It is no matter now I ha't againe.
I will not meete with you to morrow night:
I prethee Diomed visite me no more.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.l: Now shee sharpens, well said Whetstone.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: I shall haue it.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: What this?

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: I that.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: O all you gods; O pretty pretty pledge!
Thy maister now lyes thinking on his bed
Of thee and mee, and sighes, and takes my gloue,
And giues m●moriall dainty kisses to it, as I kisse thee.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Nay do not snatch it from me.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: He that takes that doth take my heart withall.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: I had your heart before, this followes it.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: I did sweare patience.
You shall not haue it Diomed, faith you shall not,
Ile giue you something else.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: I will haue this, whose was it?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: It is no matter.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Come tell me whose it was?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Twas on's that lou'd me better then you will,
But now you haue it take it.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: And by all Di●●as wayting women yond
And by her selfe I will not tell you whose.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: To morrow will I weare it on my Helme,
And grieue his spirit that dares not challenge it.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Wert thou the diuell, and wor'st it on thy horne,
It should be challengd.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Well, well, tis done, tis past: and yet it is not.
I will not keepe my word.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.p: Why then farewell, thou neuer shalt mocke Diomed againe.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.p: You shall not got: one cannot speake a word but it straight starts you.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: I doe not like this fooling.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.p: Nor I by Pluto; but that that likes not you, pleases me best.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: What shall I come? the houre—

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: I come; O Ione: do come, I shall be plagued.

sp.speaker: Dio:
sp.l: Farewell till then.

sp.speaker: Cres:
sp.l: Good night, I prethee come:
Troylus farewell, one eye yet lookes on thee,
But with my heart the other eye doth see,
Ah poore cur sex, this fault in vs I find,
The error of our eye di●ects our mind,
What error leads must erre: O then conclude,
" Mindes swayd by eyes are full of turpitude.

sp.speaker: Ther:
sp.l: A proofe of strength, she could not publish more,
Vnlesse shee said my 〈◊〉 is now turn'd whore.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: All's done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: It is.

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: Why stay we ther?

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: To make a● ecordation to my soule
Of euery sillable that here was spoke:
But if I tell how these two did Court,
Shall I not lye in publishing a truth,
Sith yet there is a credence in my heart,
An esperance so obstinatly strong,
That doth 〈◊〉, attest of eyes and eares,
As if those organs were deceptions functions,
Created onely to calumniate. Was Cresseid heere?

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: I cannot coniure Troyan.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Shee was not sure.

sp.speaker: Vlis
sp.l: Most sure she was.

sp.speaker: Troy,
sp.l: Why my negation hath no taste of madnesse.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Nor mine my Lord: Cresseid was heere but now.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Let it not be beleeu'd for woman-hood.
Thinke we had mothers, do not giue aduantage
To stub borne Critiques apt without a theme
For deptauation, to requare the generall sex
By Cresseids rule, Rather thinke this not Cresseid.

sp.speaker: Vli.
sp.l: What hath she done Prince that can spoile our mothers.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Nothing at all, vnlesse that this were she.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Will a swagger himselfe out on's owne eyes.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: This she, no this is Di●●eds Cresseida,
If beauty haue a soule this is not shee:
If soules guide vowes, if vowes be sanctimonies,
If sanctimony be the gods delight:
If there berule in vnitie it selfe,
This was not shee: O madnesse of discourse,
That cause sets vp with and against it selfe,
By-found authority: where reason can reuolt
Without perdition, and losse assume all reason,
Without reuolt▪ This is and is not Cresseid,
Within my foule there doth conduce a fight
Of this strange nature, that a thing inseparat,
Diuides more wider then the skie and earth:
And yet the spacious bredth of this diuision,
Admits no orifex for a point as subtle,
As Ariachra's broken woofe to enter,
Instance, O instance strong as Plu●●●s gates,
Cresseid is mine, tied with the bonds of heauen,
Instance, O instance, strong as heauen it selfe,
The bonds of heauen are slipt, dissolu'd and loosd,
And with another knot finde finger tied,
The fractions of her faith, orts of her loue.
The fragments, scraps, the bitts and greazie reliques.
Of her ore-eaten faith, are giuen to Diomed,

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: May worthy Troylus be halfe attached
With that which heere his passion doth expresse?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: I Greeke, and that shall be divulged well
In Characters as red as Mars his heart
Inflam'd with Venus: neuer did young man fancy
With so eternall and so fixt a soule.
Harke Greeke, as much I do Cressid loue,
So much by waight, hate I her Diomed:
That sleeue is mine, that heele beare on his Helme:
Were it a Caske compos'd by Vuleans skill
My sword should bite it: Not the dreadfull spout
Which Shipmen do the hurricano call,
Constringd in Masse by the almighty sunne
Shal dizzy with more clamour Neptunes eare, in his discent,
Then shall my prompted sword, ●alling on Diomed.

sp.speaker: Thier:
sp.l: Heele ticle it for his concupie.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: O Cressid, O false Cressid, false, false, false:
Let all vntruthes stand by thy s●ained name,
And theyle seeme glorious,

sp.speaker: Vlis:
sp.l: O containe your selfe;
Your passion drawes eares hether.

sp.speaker: Aene:
sp.l: I haue beene seeking you this houre my Lord:
Hector by this is at ming him in Troy:
Aiax your guard stayes to conduct you home.

sp.speaker: Troy:
sp.l: Haue with you Prince: my curteous Lord adiew,
Farewell reuoulted faire: and Diomed
Stand fast, and weare a Castle on thy head.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Ile bring you to the gates.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Accept distracted thankes.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: Would I could meete that roague Diomed I would croke like a Rauen. I would bode, I would bode● Patroclus will giue me any thing for the inteligence of this whore: the Pa●ot will not do more for an almond then he for a commodious drab: Lechery, lechery, still warres and lechery, nothing else holds fashion. A burning diuell take them.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: When was my Lord so much vngently temperd,
To stop his eares against admonishment:
Vnarme vnarme, and do not fight to day.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: You traine me to offend you, get you in,
By all the euerlasting gods Ile go.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: My dreames will sure prooue ominous to the day.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No more I say.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Where is my brother Hector?

sp.speaker: And,
sp.l: Here sister, arm'd and bloody in intent,
Consort with me in lowd and deere petition,
Pursue we him on knees: for I haue dreamt
Of bloudy turbulence, and this whole night
Hath nothing beene but shapes and formes of slaughter.

sp.speaker: Cass,
sp.l: O tis true.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Ho? bid my trumpet sound.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: No notes of sallie for the heauens sweete brother.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Begon I say, the gods haue heard me sweare.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The gods are dease to ho●●e and peeuish vowes,
They are polluted offrings more abhord,
Then spotted liuers in the sacrifice.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: O be perswaded, do not count it holy,
It is the purpose that makes strong the vow,
But vowes to euery purpose must not hold:
Vnarme sweet Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect,
sp.l: Hold you still I say,
Mine honor keepes the weather of my fate:
Life euery man holds deere but the deere man,
Holds honor sarre more precious deere then life,
How now yong man, meanest thou to fight to day.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Cassandra call my father to perswade.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: No faith yong Troylus, dof●e thy harnesse youth,
I am to day ith' vaine of chiualrie,
Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,
And tempt not yet the brushes of the warre.
Vnarme thee go, and doubt thou not braue boy,
Ile stand to day for thee and me and Troy.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Brother, you haue a vice of mercy in you,
Which better fits a Lion then a man.

sp.speaker: Hector.
sp.p: What vice is that? good Troylus chide mee for it.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: When many times the captiue Grecian falls,
Euen in the fanne and winde of your faire sword.
You bid them rise and liue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: O tis faire play.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Fooles play by heauen Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: for'th loue of all the gods
Lets leaue the Hermit Pitty with our Mother,
And when we haue our armors buckled on,
The venomd vengeance ride vpon our swords,
Spur them to ruthfull worke, raine them from ruth.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fie sauage, fie.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Hector then 'tis warres.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Troylus I would not haue you fight to day.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Who should with-hold me?
Not ●ate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars,
Beckning with fierie trunchion my retire,
Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees,
Their eyes ore-galled with recourse of teares,
Nor you my brother, with your true sword drawne,
Opposd to hinder me, should stop my way,

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: Lay hold vpon him, Priam hold him fast,
He is thy crutch: now if thou loose thy stay,
Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee,
Fall all together.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Come Hector, come, go back,
Thy wife hath dreamt, thy mother hath had visions,
Cassandra doth forcsee, and I my selfe,
Am like a prophet suddenly en●apt,
To tell thee that this day is ominous:
Therefore come back.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Aeneas is a field,
And I do stand, engagd to many Greekes,
Euen in the faith of valour to appeare,
This morning to them.

sp.speaker: Priam
sp.l: I but thou shalt not goe.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: I must not breake my faith,
You know me dutifall, therefore deere sir,
Let me not shame respect, but giue me leaue
To take that course by your consent and voice,
Which you do here forbid me royall Priam.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: O Priam yeeld not to him.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Do not deere father.

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: Andromache I am offended with you,
Vpon the loue you beare me get you in.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: This foolish dreaming superstitious girle,
Makes all these bo●ements.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O farewell deere Hector.
Looke how thou dy'est looke how thy eye turnes pale.
Looke how thy wounds do bleed at many vents,
Harke how Troy roares, how Hecuba cries out,
How poore Andromache shrils her dolours foorth,
Behold destruction, frenzie, and amazement,
Like witlesle an iques one another meete,
And all cric Hector, Hectors dead, O Hector.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Farewell, yet soft: Hector I take my leaue,
Thou do'st thy selfe and all our Troy deceaue?

sp.speaker: Hec.
sp.l: You are amaz'd my liege, at her exc●aime,
Goe in and cheere the towne,
Weele forth and fight,
Do deeds worth praise, and tell you them at night.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: Farewell, the gods with safetie stand about thee.

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: They are at it harke proud Diomed beleeue.
I come to loose my arme or winne my sleeue.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Do you heere my 〈…〉 ●

sp.speaker: Troyl.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Heer's a letter come from yond poore girle.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Let me read,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.p: A whorson tisick, a whorson rascally tisick, so troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girle, and what one thing, what another, that I shall leaue you one ath's dayes: and I haue a rheume in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones, that vnlesse a man were curst I cannot tell what to thinke on't. What sayes she there?

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Words, words, meere words, no matter from the heart,
Th'effect doth operate another way.
Go winde to winde, there turne and change together:
My loue with words and errors still she feedes,
But edi●ies another with her deedes.

sp.speaker: Thersi.
sp.p: Now they are clapper-clawing one another: Ile go looke on, that dislembling abhomihable vatlet Diomede, has go● that same scurnie dooting foolish knaues sleeue of Troy there in his helme. I would faine see them meete, that that same young Troy an asse that loues the whore there, might send that Greekish whore-masterly villaine with the fleeue, back to the dissembling luxurious drabbe of a sleeuelesse arrant. Ath' tother side, the pollicie of those cra●tie swearing raskalls; that stale old Mouse-eaten drye cheese Nestor: and that same dogge-foxe Vlisses, is not proou'd worth a Black-berry. They set mee vp in pollicie, that mongrill curre Aiax, against that dogge of as bad a kinde Achilles. And now is the curte Aiax, prouder then the curre Achilles, and will not arme to day. Where-vpon the Grecians began to proclaime barbarisme, and pollicie growes into an ill opinion. Soft here comes sleeue & tother.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.p: ●●lye not, for shouldst th●● take the ouer Stix, I would sw●m after,

sp.speaker: Diomed.
sp.l: Thou doost miseall re●●e,
I doe not 〈◊〉, but aduantagious care,
With-drew me from the ods of multitude, haue at thee?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Hold thy whore Grecian: now for thy whore Troian,
Now the sleeue, now the sleeue.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: What art Greeke, art thou for Hectors match.
Art thou of bloud and honour.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: No, no, I am a rascall, a scuruy rayling knaue, a very filthy roague.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: I do beleeue thee, liue.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: God a mercy, that thou wilt beleeue me, but a plague breake thy neck— for frighting me: whats become of the wenching roagues? I thinke they haue swallowed one another. I would laugh at that miracle— yet in a sort lechery eates it selfe, ile seeke them.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Goe go, my seruant take thou Troylus horse,
Present the faire steed to my Lady Cressid,
Fellow commend my seruice to her beauty:
Tell her I haue chastis'd the amorous Troyan,
And am her knight by proofe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I goe my Lord.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Renew, renew, the fierce Polidamas,
Hath beate downe Menon: bastard Margarelo●,
Hath Doreus prisoner.
And stands Colossus wise wauing his beame,
Vpon the pashed corses of the Kings:
Epistropus and Cedus, Polixines is slaine,
A●phimacus and Thous deadly hurt,
Patroclus tane or slaine, and Palamedes
Sore hurt and bruised, the dreadfull Sagittary,
Appalls our numbers, hast we Diomed,
To re-enforcement or we perish all.

sp.speaker: Nest:
sp.l: Go beare Patroclus body to Achilles,
And bid the snail-pac't Aiax arme for shame,
There is a thousand Hectors in the field:
Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
And there lacks worke, anon he's there a foote
And there they flie or die, like sealing sculls,
Before the belching Whale, then is he yonder:
And there the strawy Greekes ripe for his edge
Fall downe before him like a mowers swath,
Here, there and euery where, he leaues and takes.
Dext●●ty so ob aying appeute,
That what he will he do's, and do's so much:
That proofe is call'd impossibility.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Oh courage, courage Princes, great Achilles,
Is atming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengcance,
Patroclus wounds haue rouz'd his drowzy bloud,
Together with his mangled Myrmidons
That noselesle, handlesse, hackt and chipt come to him.
Crying on Hector, Aiax hath loft a friend,
And ●oames at mouth, and hee is armde and at it.
Roa●ing for Troylus, who hath done to day,
Madde and fantastique execution:
Engaging and redeeming of himselfe
With such a carelesse force, and forcelesse care,
As if that lust in very spi●ht of cunning, bad him win all.
Troylus, thou coward Troylus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I there, there?

sp.speaker: Nest:
sp.l: So, so we draw together.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: Where is this Hector?
Come, come, thou boy-queller shew thy face,
Know what it is to meete Achilles angry
Hector wher's Hector I will none but Hector.
Troylus thou coward Troylus shew thy head.
Troylus I say wher's Troylus?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: What wouldst thou.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: I would correct him.

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Were I the generall thou shouldst haue my office,
Ere that correction? Troylus I say what Troylus.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Oh traytor Diomed, turne thy false face thou traytor,
And pay thy life thou owe●t me for my horse.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Ha art thou there?

sp.speaker: Aiax.
sp.l: Ile fight with him alone stand Diomed.

sp.speaker: Diom.
sp.l: He is my prize, I will not looke vpon.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Come both you cogging Greekes haue at you both.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Yea Troylus, O well fought my yongest brother.
Now do I see thee ha, haue at thee Hector.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Pause if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Achil.
sp.l: I do disdaine thy curtesie proud Troyan,
Be happy that my armes are our of vse:
My rest and negligence befriends thee now,
But thou anon shalt here of me againe:
Till when goe seeke thy fortune.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Fare thee well.
I would haue beene much more a fresher man,
Had I expected thee, how now my brother.

sp.speaker: Troy.
sp.l: Aiax hath tane Aeneas, shall it be,
No by the flame of yonder glorious heauen
He shall not carry him ile be tano●o,
Or bring him off, fate here me what I say:
I wreake not though I end my life to day.

sp.speaker: Hect:
sp.l: Stand, stand thou Greeke, thou art a goodly marke,
No? wilt thou not. I like thy armor we'l,
Ile frush it and vn●oc●● the rinets all:
But ile be maister of it, wilt thou not beast abide,
Why then flie on, ile hunt thee for thy hide.
Come here about me you my Myrmidous,
Marke what I say, attend me where I wheele:
Strike not a stroke, but keepe your selues in breth,
And when I haue the bloudy Hector found:
Empale him with your weapons round about,
In fellest manner execut your armes
Follow me sirs and my proceedings eye,
It is decreed Hector the great must die.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.p: The cuck-old and the cock-old-maker are at it, now bull, now dogge lowe, Paris lowe, now my double hen'd spartan, lowe Paris, lowe the bull has the game, wate hornes ho?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: Turne slane and fight.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: A Bastard sonne of Priams.

sp.speaker: Ther's:
sp.p: I am a bastard too, I loue bastards. I am bastard be. got, bastard instructed, bastard in minde, bastard in va● our, in euery thing illigitimate, one beare wil not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard? take heed, the quarrells most ominous to vs, if the sonne of a whore ●ight for a whore, he tempts iudgement, farewell bastard.

sp.speaker: Bast.
sp.l: The diuell take thee coward.

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Most putrified core so faire without,
Thy goodly armor thus hath cost thy life;
Now is my daies worke done ile take my breth▪
